weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Enforce strong authentication and credential protection
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of Active Directory, it is essential to employ a multi-layered defense strategy involving Windows Defender Credential Guard, Privileged Access Management (PAM), and Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for administrative accounts. Additionally, adopting the principle of least privilege and restricting administrative group memberships will significantly reduce security risks.

Step-by-Step Guidance:

1. Use Windows Defender Credential Guard:

  1. Ensure your environment uses the required hardware and software configurations for Credential Guard. This typically includes Windows 10 Enterprise or Education version 1511 or later.
  2. Use Group Policy to enable Credential Guard. Navigate to Computer Configuration > Administrative Templates > System > Device Guard, and configure the Turn On Virtualization Based Security policy.
  3. Set the option to Enable with UEFI lock to fully protect credentials by locking changes to UEFI firmware settings.
  4. After enabling it, reboot the system to apply the changes effectively.

2. Enforce Privileged Access Management (PAM):

  1. Install and configure Microsoft Identity Manager (MIM) to leverage PAM. Prepare the environment by extending the Active Directory schema if necessary.
  2. Create a bastion Active Directory forest to isolate and protect privileged accounts from potential security threats in the production environment.
  3. Implement just-in-time (JIT) administration by configuring time-bound access for privileged accounts.
  4. Monitor access through comprehensive auditing to detect and respond to unauthorized access attempts.

3. Require Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for Administrative Accounts:

  1. Integrate Azure AD or another MFA solution with Active Directory to manage MFA settings.
  2. Enable Conditional Access policies to enforce MFA requirements for login attempts from identified administrative accounts.
  3. Ensure that all administrative accounts register for a supported MFA method, such as using the Microsoft Authenticator app or other approved methods.
  4. Conduct regular reviews of the MFA log to identify any suspicious activities or unsuccessful login attempts.

4. Apply the Principle of Least Privilege and Restrict Administrative Group Memberships:

  1. Perform an audit to determine the current state of user rights and group memberships. Identify users with excess privileges.
  2. Revoke unnecessary privileges by adjusting permissions to the absolute minimum required for users to perform their roles.
  3. Continuously monitor group memberships and user roles to ensure they remain aligned with current operational needs and security policies.
  4. Develop a regular compliance check routine to ensure adherence to the principle of least privilege across all Active Directory components.

References

  • Credential Guard
  • Privileged Identity Management for Active Directory Domain Services
  • Azure Active Directory Multi-Factor Authentication
  • Best practices for securing Active Directory

countermeasure.name: Harden NTDS.dit file and prevent offline attacks
countermeasure.desc:
Enhancing the security of your Active Directory setup is crucial to maintaining the integrity and confidentiality of your network. To fortify the protection of domain controllers, implement the following countermeasures:

  1. Enable Full Disk Encryption on Domain Controllers:
    1. Access the domain controller's interface and launch the BitLocker Drive Encryption tool, which is available on Windows Server editions.
    2. Select the drive you wish to encrypt and click on the "Turn on BitLocker" button.
    3. Follow the on-screen instructions to choose an authentication method, such as a password or a USB startup key.
    4. Decide if you want to encrypt the used disk space only or the entire drive, with the latter being more secure.
    5. Start the encryption process and allow it to complete. This may take several hours depending on the size of the disk.
  2. Apply NTDS Audit Logging:
    1. Open the Group Policy Management Console and navigate to the appropriate GPO that is applied to the Domain Controllers OU.
    2. Edit the GPO to configure security auditing by enabling the "Directory Service Access" audit policy under Computer Configuration Policies Windows Settings Security Settings Advanced Audit Policy Configuration DS Access.
    3. Additionally, enable logging of Directory Service Changes to track changes made to Active Directory objects.
    4. Ensure that logs are regularly archived and reviewed for any unauthorized attempts to access or modify the directory.
  3. Restrict Access to Backup Copies of NTDS.dit:
    1. Identify where backups of Active Directory database (NTDS.dit) are stored and ensure that storage locations are secure with restricted physical and network access.
    2. Utilize access control measures to limit access permissions to only essential personnel and systems.
    3. Implement file-level encryption on backup files to add an additional layer of security.
    4. Periodically review access permissions and modify them according to the principle of least privilege.
  4. Regular Monitoring for Suspicious Access to Database Files:
    1. Set up a monitoring solution such as System Center Operations Manager (SCOM) or Windows Event Viewer to track and alert on any unauthorized attempts to access NTDS.dit or related files.
    2. Implement automated alerting mechanisms to notify administrators immediately upon detection of any suspicious activities.
    3. Conduct regular audits and forensic analyses of logs to detect patterns or signs of potential compromise.

References

  • BitLocker Overview
  • Advanced Security Audit Policy Settings
  • Active Directory Data Store

countermeasure.name: Implement automated account lifecycle management
countermeasure.desc:
1. Audit Active Directory Accounts: Begin by conducting a comprehensive audit of all Active Directory accounts. This can be done using native tools like PowerShell or third-party auditing software. Run scripts to identify accounts that have been inactive for a set period, typically 30, 60, or 90 days, depending on your organization's policy.
  2. Utilize Automated Account Cleanup Scripts: Develop or utilize existing PowerShell scripts to automate the identification and disablement of inactive accounts. Ensure these scripts are scheduled to run at regular intervals to maintain consistency. An example command might be:
    Search-ADAccount -AccountInactive -TimeSpan 90.00:00:00 | Disable-ADAccount
  3. Implement Azure AD Identity Protection: If your organization uses Azure AD, leverage its Identity Protection features, which automatically identify and disable unused accounts based on user risk and activity levels. Set configurations to log detected risks and notify administrators for further action.
  4. Conditional Access Policies: Configure conditional access policies within Azure AD to restrict access for accounts flagged as stale. This involves creating policies that block or limit access based on account activity reports. For example, set policies to require MFA for users who havent logged in recently.
  5. Periodic Review and Confirmation: Integrate a process for periodic review and confirmation of disabled accounts with respective department managers to ensure no critical account is erroneously disabled. This step should also involve re-evaluating account statuses and enabling those that have been validated as needed again.
  6. Documentation and Alerts: Document all account changes and configure monitoring systems to alert IT administrators about account disablement actions. Maintain logs for compliance and auditing purposes.
  7. Educate and Communicate: Regularly educate staff on the importance of maintaining active accounts, and communicate policy changes regarding inactive account management. This ensures that users understand the rationale behind these security protocols.

References

  • Best Practices for Securing Active Directory
  • Azure AD Conditional Access Overview
  • Active Directory PowerShell Module

countermeasure.name: Implement GPO change auditing and rollback mechanisms
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing enhanced security measures for Active Directory can significantly reduce the risk of unauthorized modifications and potential breaches. Follow these steps to reinforce Group Policy Object (GPO) security:

  1. Enable Advanced GPO Auditing:
    • Open the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).
    • Navigate to the specific GPO you wish to audit.
    • Right-click on the GPO and select "Edit" to open the Group Policy Management Editor.
    • Go to Computer Configuration > Policies > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Advanced Audit Policy Configuration.
    • Configure appropriate policies under "Policy Change" such as "Audit Policy Change" and ensure "Success" and "Failure" are checked to monitor both successful and failed attempts.
    • Apply the changes and exit the editor.
  2. Configure Windows Event Logging:
    • Access the Windows Event Viewer on the Domain Controller.
    • Under "Event Viewer", go to Windows Logs > Security.
    • Review and, if necessary, enhance logging for events - especially Event IDs relevant to GPO changes (Event IDs like 5136, 5137, 5138, and 5139 for Directory Service Changes).
    • Ensure logs are maintained and stored securely, using suitable retention policies to avoid unauthorized alteration or loss.
  3. Utilize Microsoft Defender for Identity:
    • Ensure Microsoft Defender for Identity is deployed within your network. For new installations, refer to the Microsoft Defender for Identity documentation.
    • Monitor the dashboard for suspicious activities such as unusual GPO modifications.
    • Configure alerts to notify administrators of potential credential theft or illicit changes.
  4. Implement GPO Versioning and Regular Integrity Checks:
    • Periodically export GPO settings using PowerShell scripts or GPMC to maintain a version history.
    • Compare current GPOs with saved baselines to identify unauthorized changes using tools like GPOCompare or similar.
    • Conduct regular audits and check the integrity of GPO settings against this archived baseline.
    • Integrate the use of automated tools that can detect changes and revert to the last known good configuration if unauthorized modifications are detected.

By following these guidelines, you can bolster the security of your Active Directory environment, deterring adversaries and securing sensitive infrastructure against unauthorized changes.

References

  • Securing Active Directory: Group Policy Security
  • Microsoft Defender for Identity Documentation

countermeasure.name: Implement tiered administrative access model
countermeasure.desc:
1. Understand the Tiered Administrative Model: Familiarize yourself with Microsofts recommended tiered administrative model which stratifies directory administration into three distinct tiers. These are:
    • Tier 0: Direct access to domain controllers, including all associated resources like schema admins, domain admins, and enterprise admins.
    • Tier 1: Access to server management, including member servers and applications.
    • Tier 2: Access limited to user workstations and handling end-user support tasks.
  2. Identify and Categorize Accounts: Conduct an audit of all privileged accounts currently within your Active Directory environment. Categorize these accounts according to the tiered model based on the level of access they require.
  3. Implement a Separation of Accounts: For administrators with duties across different tiers, create separate accounts for each tier. For example, an admin who manages both domain controllers and member servers should have at least two accountsone dedicated to Tier 0 tasks and another for Tier 1 tasks. This separation limits the access scope if one account is compromised.
  4. Deploy Dedicated Administrative Workstations (DAWs): Set up secure, hardened workstations that are solely used for administrative tasks involving privileged accounts. Configure these workstations to restrict access to risky activities like web browsing or personal email to mitigate potential exposure vectors.
  5. Configure Access Controls: Implement strong access control policies that enforce these boundaries. Use group policies to ensure that privileged accounts cannot log onto lower-tier resources and vice versa. Additionally, configure network access policies to restrict where these accounts can be used.
  6. Regular Monitoring and Auditing: Implement continuous monitoring and regular auditing processes. Use security information and event management (SIEM) tools to observe for any unauthorized attempts to use high-privilege accounts inappropriately. Consider using Microsoft Advanced Threat Analytics (ATA) or similar solutions to detect anomalous activities.
  7. Training and Awareness: Educate all administrators about the new tiered structure and emphasize the importance of using DAWs for sensitive operations. Ensure they understand the procedures and the security rationale behind them.
  8. Review and Update Policies Regularly: Periodically review the tiered administrative model implementation and update policies as needed to adapt to new threats or changes in infrastructure.

References

  • Microsoft Security Best Practices for Active Directory - Implementing Tiered Administrative Model

countermeasure.name: Monitor and restrict domain controller promotions
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Active Directory environment, it is crucial to implement strict controls over who can promote domain controllers and to monitor relevant activities. Follow these step-by-step instructions to implement the recommended countermeasure:

Step 1: Restrict Permissions for Domain Controller Promotion

  1. Log in to the Active Directory with a user account that has the necessary administrative privileges.
  2. Open the Active Directory Users and Computers (ADUC) console.
  3. Navigate to the 'Delegate Control' wizard for the specific Organizational Unit (OU) where domain controllers are managed.
  4. Select or add the user or group that requires permission to promote domain controllers.
  5. Assign the minimum required permissions necessary, following the principle of least privilegetypically, only the permissions for domain creation and removal should be granted.
  6. Review and apply the changes. Regularly audit these permissions to ensure only authorized users have these rights.

Step 2: Monitor Domain Controller Replication Traffic

  1. Enable Network Monitoring on your Windows Servers using tools like Microsoft Message Analyzer or Wireshark.
  2. Configure filtering to capture only traffic that is relevant to domain controller replication, focusing on protocols such as Kerberos, NTLM, and LDAP.
  3. Establish baseline traffic patterns and investigate any anomalies, especially during off-peak hours.
  4. Consider implementing scripts or automated alerts for unusual patterns, which could indicate replication anomalies or unauthorized replication activities.

Step 3: Enable Security Auditing for Replication-related Events

  1. Navigate to Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) on your domain controller.
  2. Edit the Default Domain Controllers Policy or create a new policy linked to the Domain Controllers OU.
  3. Go to Computer Configuration Policies Windows Settings Security Settings Advanced Audit Policy Configuration Audit Policies Account Management.
  4. Enable auditing for Directory Service Changes and Replication and Synchronization attempts. This can be done by selecting the Success and Failure options where applicable.
  5. Audit events will be logged in the Security Logs, accessible through the Event Viewer. Regularly review these logs for any unusual activity.

Step 4: Implement Microsoft Defender for Identity

  1. Install and configure Microsoft Defender for Identity, following the best practice setup guidelines provided by Microsoft.
  2. Once operational, configure alerts for suspicious activities such as DCShadow attacks, which involve unauthorized replication requests.
  3. Use the Defender for Identity portal to monitor alerts and take corrective actions upon receiving alerts related to unauthorized DCShadow activities.

It is important to keep all software updated and conduct regular reviews to ensure compliance with these security practices.

References

  • Best Practices for Securing Active Directory.
  • Microsoft Defender for Identity

countermeasure.name: Regularly rotate KRBTGT account passwords
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the Active Directory and mitigate risks associated with credential exposure, particularly in the event of a suspected compromise, it is essential to regularly reset the KRBTGT account password and leverage Group Managed Service Accounts (gMSAs). The following detailed guidance outlines the step-by-step process for implementing this security countermeasure effectively.

Step 1: Prepare for KRBTGT Password Reset

  • Identify a time window with minimal disruption, as resetting the KRBTGT account twice will affect Kerberos ticket issuance.
  • Ensure appropriate administrative privileges are available, specifically Domain Admin or equivalent permissions.
  • Create a backup of the Active Directory database to prevent any data loss due to unforeseen issues during the password reset process.

Step 2: First KRBTGT Password Reset

  • Open the Active Directory Users and Computers (ADUC) tool.
  • In the "View" menu, ensure "Advanced Features" is selected to view hidden system accounts.
  • Navigate to Users, locate the KRBTGT account, right-click, and select "Reset Password."
  • Enter a new password that complies with your organizations password policy.
  • Document this change in your security logs for auditing purposes.

Step 3: Second KRBTGT Password Reset

  • After a minimum interval of 10 hours, repeat the password reset process to ensure all tickets utilizing the old password are expired.
  • Use the ADUC tool and follow the same procedure to reset the KRBTGT password a second time.
  • Again, document this change thoroughly.

Step 4: Implement Group Managed Service Accounts (gMSAs)

  • Validate the group policys ability to support gMSAs by using Windows Server 2012 or newer versions.
  • For Kerberos authentication, prepare the Active Directory environment by ensuring the Key Distribution Service (KDS) root key is configured:
    • Run PowerShell as an administrator and execute the command: Add-KDSRootKey -EffectiveImmediately.
  • Create the gMSA accounts with the PowerShell command:
    • New-ADServiceAccount -Name gMSA_Name -DNSHostName Domain_Name -PrincipalsAllowedToRetrieveManagedPassword "YourServerName"
  • Assign the gMSA to the relevant services using service configuration or Group Policy Objects (GPOs) to minimize service disruption.

Step 5: Monitor and Verify

  • Ensure monitoring is in place for anomalous authentication attempts or failures following the KRBTGT reset.
  • Validate all services are functioning as expected with the new gMSAs and adjust configurations if any service disruptions occur.
  • Regularly review audit logs to ensure that KRBTGT password resets and gMSA operations are logged appropriately and that security measures are maintained.

References

  • Group Managed Service Accounts Overview

countermeasure.name: Restrict delegation and monitor delegation settings
countermeasure.desc:
• Disable Unconstrained Delegation:
    • Open the Active Directory Users and Computers (ADUC) console with administrative privileges.
    • Navigate through the directory to locate computers, users, or service accounts configured for delegation.
    • Right-click on the object and select "Properties."
    • Go to the "Delegation" tab and ensure that "Trust this user/computer for delegation to any service (Kerberos only)" is not selected.
    • Select either "Do not trust this user/computer for delegation" or configure constrained delegation if necessary.
    • Apply the changes and document the modifications for future audits.
  • Principle of Least Privilege:
    • Review all accounts to identify those that require delegation and determine the minimal necessary permissions.
    • For each identified account, have a detailed mapping of required services to which it needs delegated access.
    • Modify the delegation settings to provide permissions only to the necessary services, strictly adhering to the data gathered.
    • Verify the configuration by using tools or scripts to simulate the permissions and ensure no excessive privileges are granted.
  • Regularly Audit Delegation Settings:
    • Establish a routine schedule to review delegation settings across all domain-joined assets.
    • Utilize PowerShell scripts to extract delegation configurations for automated reports.
    • Analyze these reports to detect any unauthorized or spurious delegation configurations.
    • Document and remediate unauthorized delegations promptly and adjust procedures to prevent recurrence.
  • Leverage Microsoft Defender for Identity:
    • Ensure Microsoft Defender for Identity is deployed across your network environment.
    • Configure alerts for delegation abuse, which includes monitoring for anomalous activities such as abnormal Kerberos ticket-granting services (TGS) requests.
    • Review triggered alerts daily and investigate any suspicious behaviors thoroughly.
    • Implement corrective actions based on alert findings to strengthen security controls, prevent abuse, and adjust settings accordingly.

References

  • Getting Started with Group Managed Service Accounts
  • Microsoft Defender ATP and Least Privilege

countermeasure.name: Secure and monitor domain controllers
countermeasure.desc:
Securing Active Directory is critical to maintaining an organization's network integrity. Implementing physical and logical security measures helps protect domain controllers and their access. The following steps outline a comprehensive approach to enhancing the security of Active Directory:

  1. Physically Secure Domain Controllers:
    • Identify all locations housing domain controllers. Confirm that these locations are physically secure with controlled access through locks, security personnel, and surveillance systems.
    • Restrict physical access to only authorized personnel who require it for maintenance or administration. Maintain a record of individuals with access privileges.
  2. Restrict Direct Login Access:
    • Utilize Group Policy to prevent direct user logins to domain controllers. Instead, require users to use remote administration tools or secure terminals for access.
    • Configure local security policies to restrict login events and ensure only administrative accounts necessary for operations have login privileges.
  3. Implement Centralized Logging with Windows Event Forwarding:
    • Configure Windows Event Forwarding (WEF) to collect logs from all domain controllers. Ensure these logs are sent to a centralized logging server for monitoring and analysis.
    • Regularly review and audit the logs for anomalous activities such as failed login attempts, unauthorized access attempts, or changes to security settings.
  4. Regularly Audit Privileged Access:
    • Establish a procedure for regular audits of privileged accounts, ensuring each account is regularly evaluated for necessity and security compliance.
    • Create reports of privileged access patterns and adjust privileges as necessary to adhere to the principle of least privilege.
  5. Enable Advanced Threat Detection:
    • Implement Microsoft Advanced Threat Analytics (ATA) or Microsoft Defender for Identity to automatically detect and respond to suspicious activities related to Active Directory.
    • Ensure these tools are updated to their latest versions and configure them to alert the security team immediately upon detection of suspicious behavior.

Regularly testing and updating these strategies is crucial as threats evolve. By integrating physical security, access restrictions, centralized logging, privileged audits, and advanced threat detection, organizations can significantly mitigate the risks associated with Active Directory compromises.

References

  • Securing Domain Controllers Against Attack

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Kerberos ticket forging (Golden Ticket attack)
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers who have infiltrated the KRBTGT account gain the capability to forge authentication tickets, which allows them to maintain prolonged and undetected access throughout the network's domain.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders or external threat actors who manipulate or gain unauthorized access to domain controllers with the aim of obtaining elevated privileges.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, severe disruption of domain operations, potential loss of trust in domain services, and increased risk of further security breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a domain controller, extracts credentials for the KRBTGT account, and leverages those credentials to craft unauthorized Kerberos tickets, allowing them to access critical domain resources without detection for extended periods.

threat.name: Privilege escalation through misconfigured delegation
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper configuration of delegation settings may lead to unauthorized privilege escalation by enabling attackers to impersonate accounts with elevated permissions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit incorrect delegation settings through network access to Active Directory; they can manipulate account properties or leverage existing administrative tools to execute malicious actions.
Impacts
Such activities can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of services, and potential compromise of the entire directory infrastructure.
Example Attack Scenarios
An adversary gains access to a low-level account but can alter delegation settings due to improper configurations. By doing so, they impersonate a domain admin account, gaining full control over the directory and critical systems.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to privileged accounts
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers might exploit vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access to privileged accounts, which would enable them to manipulate user data or escalate privileges within the Active Directory.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors could use techniques such as phishing, credential stuffing, or exploiting software vulnerabilities to compromise privileged account credentials.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to critical systems and data, potential data breaches, financial loss, and damage to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker phishes an administrator's credentials and subsequently uses these to alter user permissions, granting themselves or others unauthorized access to sensitive information. Another scenario could involve an attacker exploiting a known vulnerability in the Active Directory software to bypass existing security measures and escalate their privileges.

threat.name: Domain controller compromise
threat.desc:
General threat description
Gaining unauthorized control over a domain controller can lead to severe security breaches within an enterprise environment. An intruder can potentially manipulate directory data, establish persistent access, and subvert organizational control mechanisms, resulting in widespread compromise of enterprise resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit vulnerabilities in software, use social engineering techniques, or leverage misconfigurations to gain unauthorized domain controller access, allowing them to perform malicious activities.
Impacts
The primary impacts include compromise of sensitive information, creation of unauthorized access paths, disruption of operations, and potential data loss or tampering. This control can lead to a significant security breach affecting the entire enterprise environment.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker phishes a credentialed user within an organization, obtaining access rights to the domain controller and subsequently creating hidden accounts with elevated privileges. Another scenario involves exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities on the domain controller to execute arbitrary code, facilitating unauthorized modifications to directory data or system settings.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery

threat.name: Rogue domain controller attacks (DCShadow)
threat.desc:
General threat description
An unauthorized individual with elevated permissions may introduce a compromised domain controller into the network, allowing them to introduce harmful entities and disrupt system operations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
This type of threat is typically executed by malicious insiders or those who have obtained elevated credentials, utilizing administrative tools to gain unauthorized control over domain infrastructure.
Impacts
Such actions can lead to unauthorized data access, compromise of sensitive information, network degradation, and potential downtime, impacting the overall security posture and operational capabilities.
Example Attack Scenarios
A rogue administrator sets up a counterfeit domain controller within the network, manipulating the directory service to add unauthorized users with elevated privileges or to destabilize authentication protocols, facilitating further exploitation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1484 - Domain or Tenant Policy Modification

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Active Directory database theft
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers who gain unauthorized access to a copy of the Active Directory database can extract sensitive password hashes for further exploitation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals, insiders, or malicious actors leveraging vulnerabilities in system defenses to access or steal the Active Directory database.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to systems, data breaches, and potential for privilege escalation within the network, leading to further compromises.
Example Attack Scenarios
A hacker gains access to the network, locates the NTDS.dit file, and obtains password hashes to crack them offline, resulting in access to multiple user accounts and escalating privileges to compromise critical systems.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1003 - OS Credential Dumping

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Credential theft and lateral movement
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers can exploit weaknesses in authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access and move laterally across a network by utilizing stolen credentials.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals can deploy tools and techniques like pass-the-hash, pass-the-ticket, or credential dumping to capture and reuse authentication tokens or credentials.
Impacts
Such attacks can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive systems, potential data breaches, and the compromise of entire network environments due to privilege escalation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a low-level account and captures credential hashes, then uses pass-the-hash to authenticate as a domain administrator, bypassing standard security controls and gaining control of critical network assets.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

threat.name: Inactive and orphaned accounts
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inactive or orphaned user and service accounts present a security risk as they can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access and navigate laterally across the network domain.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors can identify and misuse these abandoned accounts by deploying techniques such as credential stuffing, password guessing, or leveraging leaked credentials.
Impacts
Unauthorized access gained through these accounts can lead to loss of sensitive data, disruption of services, or compromise of additional accounts and systems within the network.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers credentials for an orphaned account through a data breach and uses them to log into the system, subsequently escalating privileges and accessing confidential information stored within the domain.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Malicious modifications to group policy objects (GPOs)
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized individuals gaining access to GPOs can result in severe security modifications that jeopardize the integrity of systems.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors exploiting weak permission settings or vulnerabilities in the Active Directory system to gain unauthorized access to Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
Impacts
Alteration of crucial security rules, deactivation of security measures, and establishment of ongoing unauthorized access to infiltrated systems.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker can change password policies to steal credentials more easily or disable firewall settings to allow further penetration into the network, or they may create a custom GPO that adds their user account to a local administrator group on all computers.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1484.001 - Group Policy Modification

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Enable threat detection capabilities
countermeasure.desc:
Use the threat detection capability of Microsoft Defender for Cloud for the respective Azure services.
For threat detection not included in Microsoft Defender services, refer to Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark service baselines for the respective services to enable the threat detection or security alert capabilities within the service. Ingest alerts and log data from Microsoft Defender for Cloud, Microsoft 365 Defender, and log data from other resources into your Azure Monitor or Microsoft Sentinel instances to build analytics rules, which hunt detect threats and create alerts that match specific criteria across your environment.
For Operational Technology (OT) environments that include computers that control or monitor Industrial Control System (ICS) or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) resources, use Microsoft Defender for IoT to inventory assets and detect threats and vulnerabilities.
For services that do not have a native threat detection capability, consider collecting the data plane logs and analyze the threats through Microsoft Sentinel.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Separate and limit highly privileged/administrative users
countermeasure.desc:
You must secure all roles with direct or indirect administrative access to Azure hosted resources.
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's default identity and access management service. The most critical built-in roles in Azure AD are Global Administrator and Privileged Role Administrator, because users assigned to these two roles can delegate administrator roles. With these privileges, users can directly or indirectly read and modify every resource in your Azure environment: - Global Administrator / Company Administrator: Users with this role have access to all administrative features in Azure AD as well as services that use Azure AD identities. - Privileged Role Administrator: Users with this role can manage role assignments in Azure AD, as well as within Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM). In addition, this role allows management of all aspects of PIM and administrative units.
Outside of Azure AD, Azure has built-in roles that can be critical for privileged access at the resource level. - Owner: Grants full access to manage all resources, including the ability to assign roles in Azure RBAC. - Contributor: Grants full access to manage all resources, but does not allow you to assign roles in Azure RBAC, manage assignments in Azure Blueprints, or share image galleries. - User Access Administrator: Lets you manage user access to Azure resources. Note: You may have other critical roles that need to be governed if you use custom roles in the Azure AD level or resource level with certain privileged permissions assigned.
In addition, users with the following three roles in Azure Enterprise Agreement (EA) portal should also be restricted as they can be used to directly or indirectly manage Azure subscriptions. - Account Owner: Users with this role can manage subscriptions, including the creation and deletion of subscriptions. - Enterprise Administrator: Users assigned with this role can manage (EA) portal users. - Department Administrator: Users assigned with this role can change account owners within the department.
Lastly, ensure that you also restrict privileged accounts in other management, identity, and security systems that have administrative access to your business-critical assets, such as Active Directory Domain Controllers (DCs), security tools, and system management tools with agents installed on business-critical systems. Attackers who compromise these management and security systems can immediately weaponize them to compromise business critical assets.

countermeasure.name: Use centralized identity and authentication system
countermeasure.desc:
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's identity and authentication management service. You should standardize on Azure AD to govern your organization's identity and authentication in: - Microsoft cloud resources, such as Azure Storage, Azure Virtual Machines (Linux and Windows), Azure Key Vault, PaaS, and SaaS applications. - Your organization's resources, such as applications on Azure, third-party applications running on your corporate network resources, and third-party SaaS applications. - Your enterprise identities in Active Directory by synchronization to Azure AD to ensure a consistent and centrally managed identity strategy.
For the Azure services that apply, avoid use of local authentication methods and instead use Azure Active Directory to centralize your service authentications.
Note: As soon as it is technically feasible, you should migrate on-premises Active Directory-based applications to Azure AD. This could be an Azure AD Enterprise Directory, Business to Business configuration, or Business to consumer configuration.

countermeasure.name: Use customer-managed key option in data at rest encryption when required
countermeasure.desc:
Azure also provides an encryption option using keys managed by yourself (customer-managed keys) for most services.
Azure Key Vault Standard, Premium, and Managed HSM are natively integrated with many Azure Services for customer-managed key use cases. You may use Azure Key Vault to generate your key or bring your own keys.
However, using the customer-managed key option requires additional operational effort to manage the key lifecycle. This may include encryption key generation, rotation, revoke, and access control, etc.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access via local authentication bypass
threat.desc:
General threat description
The unrestricted use of local authentication methods for data plane access poses a significant security threat, as it can lead to weak or outdated authentication mechanisms that are susceptible to exploitation and unauthorized access. Additionally, hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files increase the risk of credential exposure and compromise.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include external attackers, malicious insiders, or automated bots leveraging various attack vectors such as credential stuffing, password cracking, or exploiting vulnerabilities in locally managed authentication systems.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access or compromised credentials can lead to data breaches, unauthorized data manipulation, service disruptions, and potential loss of sensitive information. Moreover, hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files pose a risk of unauthorized access and potential exploitation by threat actors.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could attempt to exploit weak local authentication methods, such as default or easily guessable credentials, to gain unauthorized access to the data plane. Additionally, an attacker could target system configuration files containing hard-coded credentials, extracting them for unauthorized access to sensitive resources.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized data extraction from Container Registry
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to sensitive data at rest within the cloud environment due to lack of encryption or weak encryption controls. This could lead to potential data breaches and exposure of sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors with unauthorized access to the cloud environment, including internal bad actors or external attackers. Attack vectors could involve exploiting vulnerabilities in the data encryption implementation, misconfiguration of access controls, or unauthorized access to encryption keys.
Impacts
The impacts could include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, compliance violations, reputational damage, and financial losses. Additionally, unauthorized export of data from the container registry could result in data exfiltration and misuse of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to the cloud environment and exploits weak encryption controls to access sensitive data at rest. Additionally, an insider threat uses unauthorized export capabilities to exfiltrate sensitive data from the container registry, circumventing data plane controls and potentially leading to data leakage.

threat.name: Unauthorized public network access attempt via Azure resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Disabling public network access and deploying private endpoints help mitigate the threat of unauthorized access to Azure resources through public networks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include unauthorized users, attackers, or malicious software attempting to access Azure resources over public networks. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access attempts via the internet or other public networks.
Impacts
The impact of unauthorized access to Azure resources through public networks could result in data breaches, data loss, service disruption, or unauthorized manipulation of resources.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker attempts to gain unauthorized access to Azure resources by exploiting vulnerabilities over the public network. By bypassing security measures, the attacker gains access to sensitive data, disrupts services, or manipulates resources for malicious purposes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unauthorized access to customer data by Microsoft support personnel
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources in the cloud environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external attackers attempting to gain unauthorized access to customer data in the cloud, or compromising local admin accounts for malicious purposes.
Impacts
Potential unauthorized access to sensitive data, compromise of customer confidentiality and trust, and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a local admin account that is not properly restricted for emergency use only, and uses this elevated privilege to access and exfiltrate sensitive data from the cloud environment.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and service disruptions due to insecure configurations in Azure resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of insecure configurations in Azure resources arises from misconfigurations, non-compliance with organizational policies, or malicious actions that can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, or service disruptions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders, external attackers, or accidental misconfigurations by authorized users. Attack vectors include exploiting weak or default configurations, unauthorized access to resources, or gaining elevated privileges through misconfigurations.
Impacts
The impacts of insecure configurations can range from unauthorized data access or exfiltration, service disruptions, compliance violations, to reputational damage for the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a misconfigured Azure storage account with public access, leading to unauthorized data access or modification. Another scenario involves an attacker leveraging a misconfigured network security group to gain unauthorized access to virtual machines within an Azure environment.

countermeasure.name: Authorize AzCopy with Entra ID
countermeasure.desc:
1. Install AzCopy:
    • Visit the AzCopy documentation page to download and install the latest version of AzCopy for your operating system.
    • Follow the installation instructions specific to your OS to get AzCopy installed and configured on your machine.
  2. Set up Microsoft Entra ID (formerly Azure AD) Authentication:
    • Ensure you have the necessary permissions in Microsoft Entra ID to access the Azure Data Lake Storage.
    • Open your command-line interface and log in to AzCopy using your Microsoft Entra ID account by running the following command: 
      azcopy login
    • Follow the prompted instructions to authenticate, which typically involves opening a unique URL in your browser and entering a code provided by AzCopy.
  3. Configure Access Policies:
    • In the Azure portal, navigate to the Azure Data Lake Storage account you want to secure.
    • Under the 'Access control (IAM)' tab, ensure that the user or service principal has the necessary role assignments, such as 'Storage Blob Data Contributor' or a custom role granting the needed permissions.
  4. Transfer Data with AzCopy using Microsoft Entra ID:
    • Use AzCopy to transfer files to or from Azure Data Lake Storage by specifying the source and destination in the AzCopy command.
    • For downloading data, use: 
      azcopy copy "https://.dfs.core.windows.net/" ""
    • For uploading data, use: 
      azcopy copy "" "https://.dfs.core.windows.net/"
    • Ensure that each command runs successfully, leveraging your Microsoft Entra ID credentials for secure data transaction instead of SAS tokens.
  5. Audit Activity Logs:
    • Monitor your Azure Data Lake Storage account using Azure Monitor or Azure Sentinel for any unauthorized access or unusual activity.
    • Set alerts for specific activities or anomalies to ensure timely responses to potential security threats.

References

  • Authorize access to blobs and files using AzCopy with Microsoft Entra ID instead of relying solely on SAS tokens
  • Download and Install AzCopy

countermeasure.name: Manage ACLs using Azure Portal
countermeasure.desc:
Managing Access Control Lists (ACLs) for directories and files in Azure Data Lake Storage is an essential security practice that ensures only authorized users have access to your data. This step-by-step guide will help you manage ACLs using the Azure portal.

  1. Login to the Azure portal using your credentials.
  2. Navigate to your Azure Data Lake Storage account by using the search bar or by accessing it through the "Storage accounts" section.
  3. Once inside the Data Lake Storage account page, locate and click on the "Containers" option in the left-hand menu to view the list of containers available in your account.
  4. Open the specific container which contains the directory or file for which you want to manage ACLs.
  5. Inside the container, browse to the particular directory or file where you need to set or update the ACLs. Click on it to open the item.
  6. Click on the "Access control (IAM)" option available at the top menu to begin managing the ACLs.
  7. Here you can view the current ACL settings. To add a new ACL entry, click on the "Add" button.
  8. In the Add access control settings, select the type of entity (User, Group, or Service Principal) that you are granting access to.
    1. Enter the principal name (email or ID) of the user, group, or service principal.
    2. Define the permission levels (Read, Write, Execute) to govern access. Ensure you provide the minimum necessary permissions to follow the principle of least privilege.
  9. Review the changes you've made, ensuring they align with your organization's security policies, and then click "Apply" to set the new ACLs.

Repeat the process for any other files or directories as necessary to ensure comprehensive access controls are in place.

It's also advisable to periodically review and update ACL settings to adapt to any changes in your organization's user roles or data access requirements.

If further guidance is required, please refer to the official Microsoft documentation below:

References

  • Use the Azure portal to manage the ACLs for directories and files in Azure Data Lake Storage

countermeasure.name: Use Blob and DFS endpoints with private endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of Azure Data Lake Storage, it is crucial to configure private endpoints for both the Blob and Azure Data Lake Storage (DFS) endpoints. This ensures that traffic to these services is restricted to your virtual network, reducing exposure to potential threats.

  1. Access the Azure Portal and navigate to the resource group that contains your Data Lake Storage account.
  2. Go to your Storage Account and select the Networking option under the Settings menu.
  3. In the Networking pane, click on Private endpoint connections.
  4. Select + Private endpoint to create a new private endpoint.
  5. In the Basics tab, provide the following information:
    1. Name: Enter a unique name for the private endpoint.
    2. Region: Choose the same region as your storage account.
  6. Proceed to the Resource tab and configure the following:
    1. Resource type: Set this to Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts.
    2. Resource: Select the Data Lake Storage account that will use this endpoint.
    3. Target sub-resource:
      1. Create one private endpoint with Blob as the sub-resource.
      2. Create another private endpoint with DFS as the sub-resource.
  7. In the Networking tab, specify the Virtual Network and Subnet where the private endpoint will be connected.
  8. Finish creating the private endpoint by following through with the Summary and Review + create tabs. Verify the configuration and click Create.

Repeat the process to ensure that both Blob and DFS endpoints are configured with private endpoints to ensure comprehensive security and network isolation.

Verify the configuration by checking the Private endpoint connections in your Data Lake Storage account. Ensure that there are separate entries for Blob and DFS endpoints.

References

  • Azure Data Lake Storage Explorer

countermeasure.name: Use security groups for ACL assignments
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and manageability of Azure Data Lake Storage through Azure Active Directory (AAD) integration, it is advisable to use Microsoft Entra (previously Azure AD) security groups as the principal in Access Control List (ACL) entries. This approach not only helps to avoid exceeding Azure platform limits but also simplifies identity and access management across your resources. Follow these steps to implement this security countermeasure:

  1. Create or Use Existing Microsoft Entra Security Groups
    • Navigate to the Azure Portal.
    • Go to Azure Active Directory from the services list.
    • In the AAD dashboard, select Groups and click New group if you wish to create a new security group. Otherwise, select an existing group.
    • Specify the group type as Security and fill in the required fields such as Group name, Description, and Membership type.
    • Click Create to establish the security group.
  2. Assign Users to Security Groups
    • Within Azure Active Directory, under Groups, select your newly created or chosen security group.
    • Select the Members tab, then click Add members.
    • Search and select the relevant users you wish to include in this security group.
    • Click Select followed by Save to update the group's membership.
  3. Assign Security Groups to ACLs in Azure Data Lake Storage
    • Go back to the Azure Portal and navigate to your Data Lake Storage account.
    • Locate the Data Storage section and access the container or folder you wish to set permissions for.
    • Click on Access control (IAM) and then proceed to the Role assignments tab.
    • Select Add role assignment and choose a relevant role, such as Storage Blob Data Contributor, depending on the level of access needed.
    • In the Select dialog box, choose Members and enter the name of the security group created earlier.
    • Review and confirm the assignment by clicking Save.
  4. Verify and Test Permissions
    • Ensure users within the security groups can access resources appropriately. Test permissions by attempting to access the storage data as a group member.
    • If permissions issues arise, return to the role assignments or group memberships to amend errors.

By following these steps, you streamline management by utilizing AAD security groups in ACL configurations. This not only efficiently uses identity capabilities but also ensures that platform limits associated with ACL entries are not exceeded.

References

  • Azure Storage: Data Lake Storage Best Practices

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive role assignments or ACL entries
threat.desc:
General threat description
Exceeding the platform's limitations for role assignments or ACL entries may result in difficulties in managing permissions efficiently and securely within the Azure environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Users or administrators who unknowingly or accidentally configure permissions excessively, as well as automated scripts or applications that modify ACLs beyond recommended limits.
Impacts
Potential for security vulnerabilities due to mismanaged permissions, reduced system performance, and increased complexity in access management.
Example Attack Scenarios
An administrator mistakenly assigns excessive roles to users thinking it will cover all necessary permissions, leading to inadvertent access by unauthorized personnel, or a script that auto-configures ACL entries without checks ends up exceeding limits, resulting in failed access control processes.

threat.name: Inefficient authorization management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper authorization configurations could grant unintended access to storage accounts, putting sensitive data integrity at risk.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigured access policies or credentials to gain unauthorized access to perform operations on storage accounts.
Impacts
The compromise of data integrity could result in the alteration or unauthorized deletion of critical data, leading to potential data loss and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers a misconfigured storage account with overly permissive access settings, allowing them to alter or delete stored data without proper authorization checks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Security risks due to inadequate encryption
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper encryption, sensitive data might be exposed to interception and unauthorized access in storage accounts.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers might intercept data during transmission or gain access to unprotected data in storage.
Impacts
Sensitive data may be compromised, leading to data breaches and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts data being transferred to the storage account, or accesses data stored without encryption due to configuration oversight.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access through ACL misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured or insufficient access control list settings in storage systems can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers or malicious insiders exploiting weak ACL settings to gain access to data.
Impacts
Potential data breaches, unauthorized data exposure, and compliance violations, possibly leading to financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a storage account with lax ACL settings and accesses sensitive customer data; an insider changes ACL configurations to access restricted areas of the system without detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Enable network logging for security investigation
countermeasure.desc:
Enable and collect network security group (NSG) resource logs, NSG flow logs, Azure Firewall logs, and Web Application Firewall (WAF) logs, and logs from virtual machines via the network traffic data collection agent for security analysis to support incident investigations, and security alert generation. You can send the flow logs to an Azure Monitor Log Analytics workspace and then use Traffic Analytics to provide insights.
Collect DNS query logs to assist in correlating other network data.

countermeasure.name: Enable threat detection capabilities
countermeasure.desc:
Use the threat detection capability of Microsoft Defender for Cloud for the respective Azure services.
For threat detection not included in Microsoft Defender services, refer to Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark service baselines for the respective services to enable the threat detection or security alert capabilities within the service. Ingest alerts and log data from Microsoft Defender for Cloud, Microsoft 365 Defender, and log data from other resources into your Azure Monitor or Microsoft Sentinel instances to build analytics rules, which hunt detect threats and create alerts that match specific criteria across your environment.
For Operational Technology (OT) environments that include computers that control or monitor Industrial Control System (ICS) or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) resources, use Microsoft Defender for IoT to inventory assets and detect threats and vulnerabilities.
For services that do not have a native threat detection capability, consider collecting the data plane logs and analyze the threats through Microsoft Sentinel.

countermeasure.name: Ensure regular automated backups
countermeasure.desc:
For Azure Backup supported resources (such as Azure VMs, SQL Server, HANA databases, Azure PostgreSQL Database, File Shares, Blobs or Disks), enable Azure Backup and configure the desired frequency and retention period. For Azure VM, you can use Azure Policy to have backup automatically enabled using Azure Policy.
For resources or services not supported by Azure Backup, use the native backup capability provided by the resource or service. For example, Azure Key Vault provides a native backup capability.
For resources/services that are neither supported by Azure Backup nor have a native backup capability, evaluate your backup and disaster needs, and create your own mechanism as per your business requirements. For example: - If you use Azure Storage for data storage, enable blob versioning for your storage blobs which will allow you to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your Azure Storage. - Service configuration settings can usually be exported to Azure Resource Manager templates.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal.
The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates.
Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions.
Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Restrict the exposure of credential and secrets
countermeasure.desc:
When using a managed identity is not an option, ensure that secrets and credentials are stored in secure locations such as Azure Key Vault, instead of embedding them into the code and configuration files.
If you use Azure DevOps and GitHub for your code management platform: - Implement Azure DevOps Credential Scanner to identify credentials within the code. - For GitHub, use the native secret scanning feature to identify credentials or other forms of secrets within the code.
Clients such as Azure Functions, Azure Apps services, and VMs can use managed identities to access Azure Key Vault securely. See Data Protection controls related to the use of Azure Key Vault for secrets management.
Note: Azure Key Vault provides automatic rotation for supported services. For secrets which cannot be automatically rotated, ensure they are manually rotated periodically and purged when no longer in use.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.
