countermeasure.name: Use a secure certificate management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control the certificate lifecycle, including the creation/import, rotation, revocation, storage, and purge of the certificate. Ensure the certificate generation follows the defined standard without using any insecure properties, such as insufficient key size, overly long validity period, insecure cryptography and so on. Setup automatic rotation of the certificate in Azure Key Vault and supported Azure services based on the defined schedule and when a certificate expires. If automatic rotation is not supported in the frontend application, use a manual rotation in Azure Key Vault.
Avoid using a self-signed certificate and wildcard certificate in your critical services due to the limited security assurance. Instead, you can create public signed certificates in Azure Key Vault. The following Certificate Authorities (CAs) are the partnered providers that are currently integrated with Azure Key Vault. - DigiCert: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with DigiCert. - GlobalSign: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with GlobalSign.
Note: Use only approved CA and ensure that known bad root/intermediate certificates issued by these CAs are disabled.

reference.name: Azure Key Vault certificate management

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

countermeasure.name: Use customer-managed key option in data at rest encryption when required
countermeasure.desc:
Azure also provides an encryption option using keys managed by yourself (customer-managed keys) for most services.
Azure Key Vault Standard, Premium, and Managed HSM are natively integrated with many Azure Services for customer-managed key use cases. You may use Azure Key Vault to generate your key or bring your own keys.
However, using the customer-managed key option requires additional operational effort to manage the key lifecycle. This may include encryption key generation, rotation, revoke, and access control, etc.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unscheduled or infrequent application backups leading to potential data loss
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of data loss and downtime due to operational failure or security breaches is a concern with stateful applications, even if backup and recovery mechanisms are in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors seeking to disrupt or compromise the application and its data. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to the application and its storage, injection of malicious code, or intentional deletion or corruption of data.
Impacts
The impacts of a successful attack or operational failure could include loss of data, extended downtime, potential regulatory non-compliance, and damage to the organization's reputation and trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the application and its backup data, leading to the theft or deletion of critical information. 2. Malicious code injection results in the corruption or encryption of application data, rendering backups unusable for recovery. 3. Operational failure, such as misconfiguration or human error, causes accidental deletion or overwriting of critical data, leading to service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through misconfigured Azure RBAC role assignments
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to Azure resources can occur if Azure RBAC roles are not properly managed and assigned, leading to potential data breaches, service disruptions, or unauthorized actions within the Azure environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users gaining access to Azure resources through misconfigured or overly permissive Azure RBAC role assignments. Attack vectors may include exploiting weak authentication mechanisms, leveraging stolen credentials, or abusing overly permissive role assignments.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive data, unauthorized modification or deletion of resources, service disruptions, or unauthorized use of Azure services, leading to potential data breaches, financial loss, reputational damage, and compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an Azure subscription through compromised credentials and exploits overly permissive Azure RBAC role assignments to escalate privileges, access sensitive data, and modify critical resources without proper authorization. Alternatively, a malicious insider exploits their legitimate access to improperly assign themselves overly permissive Azure RBAC roles, allowing them to perform unauthorized actions within the Azure environment.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to misconfigured Azure Key Vault settings
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured Azure Key Vault settings can expose sensitive data to unauthorized access, leading to potential data breaches and leakage of critical information. Attackers may exploit misconfigurations to gain access to encryption keys, secrets, and certificates stored within the Key Vault, compromising the overall security of the cloud environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors leveraging automated tools to scan for misconfigured Azure Key Vaults or insiders with access to the Azure environment seeking to exploit inadequate security configurations. Attack vectors may involve brute force attacks, credential theft, and unauthorized access to Key Vault resources directly or through other compromised Azure resources.
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigured Azure Key Vaults may result in unauthorized access to sensitive data, encryption keys, and credentials. This could lead to data exfiltration, unauthorized decryption of sensitive information, and exploitation of compromised credentials, ultimately leading to reputational damage, financial loss, and non-compliance with data protection regulations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured Azure Key Vault with weak access control policies and gains unauthorized access to encryption keys and secrets. Leveraging the accessed credentials, the attacker exfiltrates sensitive data or decrypts confidential information, leading to data breaches and compliance violations.

threat.name: Insecure management of key lifecycle in Azure Key Vault
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access and compromise of certificates and keys stored in Azure Key Vault due to misconfigurations, weak security controls, or exploitation of vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders, external attackers, or individuals with unauthorized access to the Azure Key Vault. Attack vectors may involve exploiting weak access controls, leveraging stolen credentials, or abusing vulnerabilities in the key vault infrastructure.
Impacts
The impacts of a successful attack could result in unauthorized access to sensitive certificates and keys, leading to data breaches, unauthorized decryption of data, and potential compromise of sensitive systems and information.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits misconfigured access policies in Azure Key Vault, gaining unauthorized access to certificates and keys, allowing them to decrypt sensitive data or impersonate trusted entities. 2. A malicious insider abuses their privileges to improperly rotate or delete keys and certificates, leading to service disruption or data loss. 3. Vulnerabilities in the key vault infrastructure are exploited to extract sensitive key and certificate information, potentially leading to further attacks or data compromise.

threat.name: Avoid embedding credentials in code or configuration files, use secure storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing secrets and credentials in code or configuration files can lead to unauthorized access and potential exposure of sensitive information, which can pose a significant security risk.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers with access to the codebase or configuration files, insider threats, or unauthorized individuals who gain access to the application or infrastructure can exploit hardcoded credentials and secrets.
Impacts
The impacts of storing secrets and credentials in code or configuration files include potential unauthorized access to sensitive data, service or data tampering, data breaches, and loss of trust from customers and stakeholders.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the source code repository and locates hardcoded credentials, allowing them to compromise the associated Azure resources, access sensitive data, or tamper with the application's functionality. Alternatively, an unauthorized individual gains access to the configuration files on a compromised system, leading to unauthorized access to Azure resources or sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Azure Key Vault leading to data compromise
threat.desc:
General threat description
Enabling Microsoft Defender for Key Vault provides protection and detection capabilities for key management services, helping to safeguard against unauthorized access, data exfiltration, and other security threats. In the event of an alert, investigating and responding promptly is crucial to mitigate potential security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may attempt to gain unauthorized access to sensitive keys and secrets stored in the Key Vault, either through exploiting vulnerabilities in the Key Vault or through unauthorized access to the surrounding infrastructure. Attack vectors may include credential theft, exploitation of misconfigured access controls, and insider threats.
Impacts
The impact of a successful attack on the Key Vault could result in unauthorized access to sensitive keys and secrets, potential data exfiltration, and compromise of cryptographic materials. This could lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and potential impact on the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of critical systems and data.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to administrative credentials through phishing or credential theft and exfiltrates sensitive keys from the Key Vault, enabling them to decrypt and access sensitive data. Another scenario involves an insider threat misusing their authorized access to the Key Vault to retrieve and exfiltrate sensitive keys for malicious purposes.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Azure Key Vault via public network
threat.desc:
General threat description
An attacker with malicious intent may attempt to gain unauthorized access to Azure Key Vault or intercept sensitive data by exploiting the lack of proper network controls and access restrictions in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthenticated users, malicious insiders, or external attackers may attempt to bypass the network security controls or exploit misconfigured access rules to gain access to the Azure Key Vault resources.
Impacts
The impact of a successful attack could result in data breaches, theft of sensitive information, unauthorized access to encryption keys, or compromise of critical secrets stored in the Azure Key Vault.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may attempt to exploit the lack of proper IP filtering rules in the Azure Key Vault firewall to gain unauthorized access from public networks. Additionally, an attacker may try to circumvent the network security groups (NSGs) to gain access to open ports and services that are meant to be restricted to trusted networks. Finally, an attacker may attempt to intercept traffic or perform man-in-the-middle attacks on communication with the Key Vault by exploiting the absence of private endpoints or virtual network service endpoints.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Enable threat detection capabilities
countermeasure.desc:
Use the threat detection capability of Microsoft Defender for Cloud for the respective Azure services.
For threat detection not included in Microsoft Defender services, refer to Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark service baselines for the respective services to enable the threat detection or security alert capabilities within the service. Ingest alerts and log data from Microsoft Defender for Cloud, Microsoft 365 Defender, and log data from other resources into your Azure Monitor or Microsoft Sentinel instances to build analytics rules, which hunt detect threats and create alerts that match specific criteria across your environment.
For Operational Technology (OT) environments that include computers that control or monitor Industrial Control System (ICS) or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) resources, use Microsoft Defender for IoT to inventory assets and detect threats and vulnerabilities.
For services that do not have a native threat detection capability, consider collecting the data plane logs and analyze the threats through Microsoft Sentinel.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in transit
countermeasure.desc: Enforce secure transfer in services such as Azure Storage, where a native data in transit encryption feature is built in. Enforce HTTPS for web application workloads and services by ensuring that any clients connecting to your Azure resources use transport layer security (TLS) v1.2 or later. For remote management of VMs, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For remote management of Azure virtual machines, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For secure file transfer, use the SFTP/FTPS service in Azure Storage Blob, App Service apps, and Function apps, instead of using the regular FTP service. Note: Data in transit encryption is enabled for all Azure traffic traveling between Azure datacenters. TLS v1.2 or later is enabled on most Azure services by default. And some services such as Azure Storage and Application Gateway can enforce TLS v1.2 or later on the server side.

countermeasure.name: Ensure regular automated backups
countermeasure.desc: For Azure Backup supported resources (such as Azure VMs, SQL Server, HANA databases, Azure PostgreSQL Database, File Shares, Blobs or Disks), enable Azure Backup and configure the desired frequency and retention period. For Azure VM, you can use Azure Policy to have backup automatically enabled using Azure Policy. For resources or services not supported by Azure Backup, use the native backup capability provided by the resource or service. For example, Azure Key Vault provides a native backup capability. For resources/services that are neither supported by Azure Backup nor have a native backup capability, evaluate your backup and disaster needs, and create your own mechanism as per your business requirements. For example: - If you use Azure Storage for data storage, enable blob versioning for your storage blobs which will allow you to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your Azure Storage. - Service configuration settings can usually be exported to Azure Resource Manager templates.

countermeasure.name: Follow just enough administration (least privilege) principle
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) to manage Azure resource access through role assignments. Through RBAC, you can assign roles to users, groups, service principals, and managed identities. There are pre-defined built-in roles for certain resources, and these roles can be inventoried or queried through tools such as Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, and the Azure portal. The privileges you assign to resources through Azure RBAC should always be limited to what's required by the roles. Limited privileges will complement the just-in-time (JIT) approach of Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM), and those privileges should be reviewed periodically. If required, you can also use PIM to define a time-bound assignment, which is a condition in a role assignment where a user can only activate the role within the specified start and end dates. Note: Use Azure built-in roles to allocate permissions and only create custom roles when required.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Monitor anomalies and threats targeting sensitive data
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure Information protection (AIP) to monitor the data that has been classified and labeled. Use Microsoft Defender for Storage, Microsoft Defender for SQL, Microsoft Defender for open-source relational databases, and Microsoft Defender for Cosmos DB to alert on anomalous transfer of information that might indicate unauthorized transfers of sensitive data information. Note: If required for compliance of data loss prevention (DLP), you can use a host-based DLP solution from Azure Marketplace or a Microsoft 365 DLP solution to enforce detective and/or preventative controls to prevent data exfiltration.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions. Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Restrict the exposure of credential and secrets
countermeasure.desc: When using a managed identity is not an option, ensure that secrets and credentials are stored in secure locations such as Azure Key Vault, instead of embedding them into the code and configuration files. If you use Azure DevOps and GitHub for your code management platform: - Implement Azure DevOps Credential Scanner to identify credentials within the code. - For GitHub, use the native secret scanning feature to identify credentials or other forms of secrets within the code. Clients such as Azure Functions, Azure Apps services, and VMs can use managed identities to access Azure Key Vault securely. See Data Protection controls related to the use of Azure Key Vault for secrets management. Note: Azure Key Vault provides automatic rotation for supported services. For secrets which cannot be automatically rotated, ensure they are manually rotated periodically and purged when no longer in use.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Separate and limit highly privileged/administrative users
countermeasure.desc:
You must secure all roles with direct or indirect administrative access to Azure hosted resources.
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's default identity and access management service. The most critical built-in roles in Azure AD are Global Administrator and Privileged Role Administrator, because users assigned to these two roles can delegate administrator roles. With these privileges, users can directly or indirectly read and modify every resource in your Azure environment: - Global Administrator / Company Administrator: Users with this role have access to all administrative features in Azure AD as well as services that use Azure AD identities. - Privileged Role Administrator: Users with this role can manage role assignments in Azure AD, as well as within Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM). In addition, this role allows management of all aspects of PIM and administrative units.
Outside of Azure AD, Azure has built-in roles that can be critical for privileged access at the resource level. - Owner: Grants full access to manage all resources, including the ability to assign roles in Azure RBAC. - Contributor: Grants full access to manage all resources, but does not allow you to assign roles in Azure RBAC, manage assignments in Azure Blueprints, or share image galleries. - User Access Administrator: Lets you manage user access to Azure resources. Note: You may have other critical roles that need to be governed if you use custom roles in the Azure AD level or resource level with certain privileged permissions assigned.
In addition, users with the following three roles in Azure Enterprise Agreement (EA) portal should also be restricted as they can be used to directly or indirectly manage Azure subscriptions. - Account Owner: Users with this role can manage subscriptions, including the creation and deletion of subscriptions. - Enterprise Administrator: Users assigned with this role can manage (EA) portal users. - Department Administrator: Users assigned with this role can change account owners within the department.
Lastly, ensure that you also restrict privileged accounts in other management, identity, and security systems that have administrative access to your business-critical assets, such as Active Directory Domain Controllers (DCs), security tools, and system management tools with agents installed on business-critical systems. Attackers who compromise these management and security systems can immediately weaponize them to compromise business critical assets.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure certificate management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control the certificate lifecycle, including the creation/import, rotation, revocation, storage, and purge of the certificate. Ensure the certificate generation follows the defined standard without using any insecure properties, such as insufficient key size, overly long validity period, insecure cryptography and so on. Setup automatic rotation of the certificate in Azure Key Vault and supported Azure services based on the defined schedule and when a certificate expires. If automatic rotation is not supported in the frontend application, use a manual rotation in Azure Key Vault.
Avoid using a self-signed certificate and wildcard certificate in your critical services due to the limited security assurance. Instead, you can create public signed certificates in Azure Key Vault. The following Certificate Authorities (CAs) are the partnered providers that are currently integrated with Azure Key Vault. - DigiCert: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with DigiCert. - GlobalSign: Azure Key Vault offers OV TLS/SSL certificates with GlobalSign.
Note: Use only approved CA and ensure that known bad root/intermediate certificates issued by these CAs are disabled.

reference.name: Certificate Access Control in Azure Key Vault
Get started with Key Vault certificates

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

countermeasure.name: Use centralized identity and authentication system
countermeasure.desc:
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's identity and authentication management service. You should standardize on Azure AD to govern your organization's identity and authentication in: - Microsoft cloud resources, such as Azure Storage, Azure Virtual Machines (Linux and Windows), Azure Key Vault, PaaS, and SaaS applications. - Your organization's resources, such as applications on Azure, third-party applications running on your corporate network resources, and third-party SaaS applications. - Your enterprise identities in Active Directory by synchronization to Azure AD to ensure a consistent and centrally managed identity strategy.
For the Azure services that apply, avoid use of local authentication methods and instead use Azure Active Directory to centralize your service authentications.
Note: As soon as it is technically feasible, you should migrate on-premises Active Directory-based applications to Azure AD. This could be an Azure AD Enterprise Directory, Business to Business configuration, or Business to consumer configuration.

countermeasure.desc: Azure also provides an encryption option using keys managed by yourself (customer-managed keys) for most services. Azure Key Vault Standard, Premium, and Managed HSM are natively integrated with many Azure Services for customer-managed key use cases. You may use Azure Key Vault to generate your key or bring your own keys. However, using the customer-managed key option requires additional operational effort to manage the key lifecycle. This may include encryption key generation, rotation, revoke, and access control, etc.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unscheduled or infrequent application backups leading to potential data loss
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of data loss and downtime due to operational failure or security breaches is a concern with stateful applications, even if backup and recovery mechanisms are in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors seeking to disrupt or compromise the application and its data. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to the application and its storage, injection of malicious code, or intentional deletion or corruption of data.
Impacts
The impacts of a successful attack or operational failure could include loss of data, extended downtime, potential regulatory non-compliance, and damage to the organization's reputation and trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the application and its backup data, leading to the theft or deletion of critical information. 2. Malicious code injection results in the corruption or encryption of application data, rendering backups unusable for recovery. 3. Operational failure, such as misconfiguration or human error, causes accidental deletion or overwriting of critical data, leading to service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data breaches due to public endpoints in Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS)
threat.desc:
General threat description
Disabling the Public FQDN on a private Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) cluster can help mitigate the risk of unauthorized access and potential exposure of the cluster to the public internet. Deploying private endpoints for Azure resources that support Private Link further enhances the security posture by providing a private access point for the resources, reducing the exposure to public networks and potential threats. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may attempt to gain unauthorized access to the Azure Kubernetes Service cluster or the associated Azure resources by leveraging public endpoints or exploiting potential vulnerabilities. Attack vectors may include unauthorized network access, reconnaissance, and exploitation of misconfigured public endpoints. 
Impacts
Disabling the Public FQDN and deploying private endpoints can help mitigate the risk of unauthorized access, data exfiltration, and potential exposure to external threats. Failure to implement these controls can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and exploitation of public endpoints. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker attempts to gain unauthorized access to an Azure Kubernetes Service cluster by leveraging the Public FQDN and exploiting potential vulnerabilities in publicly accessible components. Without private endpoints, the attacker may also attempt to intercept or manipulate data transmitted between the Azure resources and external clients.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unauthorized use of Azure RBAC for resource access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Disabling or restricting local admin accounts for emergency use introduces the risk of unauthorized access and compromise of critical systems if emergency access is needed. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external threat actors may attempt to gain unauthorized access to systems by exploiting disabled or restricted local admin accounts. Attack vectors may include brute force attacks, privilege escalation, or exploiting vulnerabilities in other accounts or systems. 
Impacts
The compromise of disabled or restricted local admin accounts can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, system manipulation, or disruption of operations. This can result in financial loss, reputational damage, and non-compliance with security regulations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider threat actor with knowledge of emergency access procedures attempts to exploit the disabled local admin account during a critical system downtime, gaining unauthorized access and manipulating critical data. Alternatively, an external threat actor launches a brute force attack against disabled local admin accounts to gain unauthorized access to critical infrastructure.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data breaches due to insecure Azure resource configurations
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized or insecure configurations of Azure resources, leading to potential security vulnerabilities and non-compliance with organizational security policies. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors, insider threats, or accidental misconfigurations. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized access, misconfigured settings, or exploitation of vulnerabilities in Azure resources. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include increased risk of data breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive information, exposure of resources to potential attacks, and non-compliance with security standards and regulations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits a misconfigured Azure storage account with publicly accessible data, leading to unauthorized access and data exfiltration. 2. An insider intentionally misconfigures an Azure virtual machine, allowing unauthorized access to the system and potential data manipulation. 3. A misconfiguration in an Azure Key Vault leads to unauthorized access to cryptographic keys, compromising the confidentiality and integrity of sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1649 - Steal or Forge Authentication Certificates

threat.name: Data breaches and unauthorized access due to inadequate certificate lifecycle management and insecure encryption
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of inadequate management of certificate lifecycle, insecure encryption standards, and insecure transfer protocols can lead to potential data breaches, unauthorized access, and compromised data integrity in the cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit inadequate management of certificate lifecycle, insecure encryption standards, and insecure transfer protocols through various means such as unauthorized access to keys and certificates, interception of data in transit, and exploitation of vulnerabilities in encryption algorithms. 
Impacts
The impacts of such threats include potential exposure of sensitive data, unauthorized access to critical systems, compromised data integrity, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker intercepts data in transit due to insecure transfer protocols and gains unauthorized access to sensitive information. 2. Exploiting inadequate key management practices, an attacker gains access to encryption keys and decrypts confidential data stored in the cloud environment. 3. Insecure encryption standards and long validity periods lead to the compromise of certificates, allowing malicious actors to impersonate legitimate services and conduct man-in-the-middle attacks.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data breaches from default authentication methods and insecure credential storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
The use of default authentication methods or insecure storage of secrets and credentials can lead to unauthorized access and potential data breaches in the cloud environment. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors, internal users with malicious intent, or automated bots targeting insecurely stored credentials. Attack vectors could involve exploiting vulnerabilities in code or configuration files where credentials are embedded, or leveraging unauthorized access to compromise the Azure AD or Key Vault. 
Impacts
The impacts of these threats could range from unauthorized access to sensitive data, data exfiltration, service disruptions, reputational damage, and regulatory non-compliance. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains access to code or configuration files containing embedded credentials, allowing them to extract the sensitive information and compromise the systems or data they protect. 2. A malicious insider exploits default authentication methods to gain unauthorized access to the data plane, bypassing security controls and accessing confidential information. 3. A threat actor successfully compromises the insecurely stored secrets and credentials in Azure Key Vault, leading to unauthorized access to critical resources or data.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data exposure due to misconfigured Azure Load Balancer resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unsecured or misconfigured Azure Load Balancer resources can lead to potential security vulnerabilities, putting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data and services at risk. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit misconfigured Azure Load Balancer resources by taking advantage of exposed ports, unprotected network traffic, or unauthorized access to backend systems. Attack vectors include unauthorized access to the load balancer configuration, exploitation of weak security controls, and interception of unencrypted network traffic. 
Impacts
The impacts of insecure Azure Load Balancer configurations can range from unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of services due to DDoS attacks, or exposure of critical backend systems to malicious actors. This could lead to financial losses, reputational damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured Azure Load Balancer with unrestricted access to backend systems. By exploiting this misconfiguration, they are able to perform reconnaissance, launch a DDoS attack, or exfiltrate sensitive data. In another scenario, an attacker intercepts unencrypted network traffic that is not properly secured by the load balancer, leading to the exposure of sensitive information during transit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unassigned network security groups expose backend resources to unauthorized traffic
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to backend resources of a virtual network, which can occur when network security groups are not properly implemented and configured. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors can exploit this vulnerability by attempting to directly access backend resources from the internet, bypassing the intended security measures. This can be achieved by probing for open ports or using unauthorized IP address ranges. 
Impacts
The impact of this threat includes potential exposure of backend resources of the virtual network to unauthorized access, leading to data breaches, service disruption, or unauthorized usage of resources. This can compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the application and its data. 
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious actor may attempt to directly access backend resources of the virtual network by scanning for open ports and leveraging unauthorized IP address ranges. By exploiting the absence of network security groups or misconfigured rules, the attacker could gain unauthorized access to sensitive data, disrupt services, or compromise the integrity of the application.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions.
Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Restrict the exposure of credential and secrets
countermeasure.desc:
When using a managed identity is not an option, ensure that secrets and credentials are stored in secure locations such as Azure Key Vault, instead of embedding them into the code and configuration files.
If you use Azure DevOps and GitHub for your code management platform: - Implement Azure DevOps Credential Scanner to identify credentials within the code. - For GitHub, use the native secret scanning feature to identify credentials or other forms of secrets within the code.
Clients such as Azure Functions, Azure Apps services, and VMs can use managed identities to access Azure Key Vault securely. See Data Protection controls related to the use of Azure Key Vault for secrets management.
Note: Azure Key Vault provides automatic rotation for supported services. For secrets which cannot be automatically rotated, ensure they are manually rotated periodically and purged when no longer in use.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

countermeasure.name: Use customer-managed key option in data at rest encryption when required
countermeasure.desc:
Azure also provides an encryption option using keys managed by yourself (customer-managed keys) for most services.
Azure Key Vault Standard, Premium, and Managed HSM are natively integrated with many Azure Services for customer-managed key use cases. You may use Azure Key Vault to generate your key or bring your own keys.
However, using the customer-managed key option requires additional operational effort to manage the key lifecycle. This may include encryption key generation, rotation, revoke, and access control, etc.

countermeasure.name: Use modern anti-malware software
countermeasure.desc:
Microsoft Defender for Cloud can automatically identify the use of a number of popular anti-malware solutions for your virtual machines and on-premises machines with Azure Arc configured and report the endpoint protection running status and make recommendations.
Microsoft Defender Antivirus is the default anti-malware solution for Windows server 2016 and above. For Windows server 2012 R2, use Microsoft Antimalware extension to enable SCEP (System Center Endpoint Protection). For Linux VMs, use Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Linux for the endpoint protection feature.
For both Windows and Linux, you can use Microsoft Defender for Cloud to discover and assess the health status of the anti-malware solution.
Note: You can also use Microsoft Defender for Cloud's Defender for Storage to detect malware uploaded to Azure Storage accounts.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Pre-installed ClamAV can be used to bypass malware detection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Installing ClamAV may pose a threat to system security if not properly configured and maintained.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may exploit misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in ClamAV to launch malware or exploit attacks against the compute instance. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to ClamAV's signature databases or exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities in ClamAV software.
Impacts
The impacts of a misconfigured or compromised ClamAV instance may include the introduction of malware into the system, unauthorized access to sensitive information, and disruption of normal system operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
A threat actor exploits a known vulnerability in a specific version of ClamAV to gain unauthorized access to the compute instance and install malicious software. This software then exfiltrates sensitive data from the system, causing a data breach and potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation||ATLAS - AML.T0011 - User Execution

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to customer-managed encryption keys and data exfiltration
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to sensitive data at rest in cloud environments where encryption using customer-managed keys is not implemented can lead to data exposure and potential regulatory non-compliance.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized third-party applications. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized access to storage resources, exploitation of vulnerabilities, or misconfiguration leading to unauthorized data access.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat could include unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data, regulatory non-compliance, reputational damage, and financial loss due to potential fines or legal actions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to the storage account and exfiltrates sensitive data stored in its unencrypted form. This data breach results in regulatory non-compliance and reputational damage to the organization. Alternatively, a malicious insider abuses their privileges to access and extract sensitive data from the storage resources, circumventing existing controls and leading to potential misuse of the information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1020 - Automated Exfiltration||ATLAS - AML.T0025 - Exfiltration via Cyber Means

threat.name: Improper storage and handling of credentials and secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing secrets and credentials in code or configuration files presents a security risk, as unauthorized access or exposure of these credentials can lead to data breaches, unauthorized access, and potential compromise of sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents or attack vectors for this threat include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users who gain access to the code or configuration files. Attack vectors can include unauthorized access to version control systems, unauthorized viewing of configuration files, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the application code.
Impacts
The potential impacts of unauthorized access to embedded secrets and credentials include data breaches, unauthorized system access, compromised sensitive information, and potential compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the source code repository of an application and identifies embedded credentials. By extracting these credentials, the attacker gains unauthorized access to critical systems or sensitive data, leading to a data breach and potential reputational damage for the organization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552 - Unsecured Credentials||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized configuration changes detected in Azure resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured cloud resources can lead to security vulnerabilities, unauthorized access, data breaches, and compliance violations. Threat actors may leverage misconfigurations to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data, disrupt services, or conduct other malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents, such as malicious hackers, insider threats, and automated bots, may exploit misconfigured Azure resources to gain unauthorized access, exfiltrate data, tamper with configurations, or disrupt services. Attack vectors include exploiting weak access controls, unsecured network configurations, and misconfigured security settings.
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigured Azure resources include unauthorized access, data leaks, service disruptions, regulatory non-compliance, financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences. Additionally, misconfigured resources can lead to exploitation of vulnerabilities, lateral movement within the cloud environment, and compromise of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured storage account in Azure with overly permissive access control settings. The attacker exploits this misconfiguration to exfiltrate sensitive data stored within the storage account, leading to a data breach. Additionally, the attacker may modify or delete critical data, causing operational disruption and financial loss for the organization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578 - Modify Cloud Compute Infrastructure||ATLAS - AML.T0049 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Enforce secure transfer in services such as Azure Storage, where a native data in transit encryption feature is built in.
Enforce HTTPS for web application workloads and services by ensuring that any clients connecting to your Azure resources use transport layer security (TLS) v1.2 or later. For remote management of VMs, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol.
For remote management of Azure virtual machines, use SSH (for Linux) or RDP/TLS (for Windows) instead of an unencrypted protocol. For secure file transfer, use the SFTP/FTPS service in Azure Storage Blob, App Service apps, and Function apps, instead of using the regular FTP service.
Note: Data in transit encryption is enabled for all Azure traffic traveling between Azure datacenters. TLS v1.2 or later is enabled on most Azure services by default. And some services such as Azure Storage and Application Gateway can enforce TLS v1.2 or later on the server side.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Manage application identities securely and automatically
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure managed identities, which can authenticate to Azure services and resources that support Azure AD authentication. Managed identity credentials are fully managed, rotated, and protected by the platform, avoiding hard-coded credentials in source code or configuration files.
For services that don't support managed identities, use Azure AD to create a service principal with restricted permissions at the resource level. It is recommended to configure service principals with certificate credentials and fall back to client secrets for authentication.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions.
Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Use customer-managed key option in data at rest encryption when required
countermeasure.desc:
Azure also provides an encryption option using keys managed by yourself (customer-managed keys) for most services.
Azure Key Vault Standard, Premium, and Managed HSM are natively integrated with many Azure Services for customer-managed key use cases. You may use Azure Key Vault to generate your key or bring your own keys.
However, using the customer-managed key option requires additional operational effort to manage the key lifecycle. This may include encryption key generation, rotation, revoke, and access control, etc.
