usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data exposure and compromise due to inadequate encryption and secure transfer in Azure services
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to sensitive data at rest and in transit within Azure services, potentially leading to data exposure and compromise.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious actors seeking to exploit vulnerabilities in data encryption or transfer processes, as well as unauthorized users attempting to intercept or access data in transit or at rest.
Impacts
The impacts could include unauthorized access to sensitive information, data theft, data tampering, and potential non-compliance with regulatory requirements. This could result in financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences for the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an Azure service lacking data at rest encryption using customer-managed keys, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive customer data. Alternatively, an attacker intercepts unsecured data in transit, potentially exposing confidential financial or personal information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to misconfigured Azure AD conditional access and unprotected service principals
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to Azure resources and services due to misconfigured or unprotected Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) conditional access and the use of unauthorized service principals, posing a risk to the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of sensitive data and critical workloads.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized third-party applications exploiting misconfigured conditional access policies. Attack vectors include unauthorized access attempts from specific locations, exploitation of risky sign-in behavior, or abuse of service principals with hard-coded credentials.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive data and critical workloads, potential data breaches, loss of data integrity, disruptions to business operations, and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker leverages compromised credentials to bypass misconfigured conditional access policies, gaining unauthorized access to critical Azure resources from a restricted location. 2. A malicious insider manipulates risky sign-in behavior to evade conditional access controls and gain unauthorized access to sensitive data within Azure workloads. 3. Unauthorized third-party applications exploit unprotected service principals with hard-coded credentials, leading to unauthorized authentication and access to Azure services and resources.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to customer log data by Microsoft support personnel
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to customer data by Microsoft or its employees when performing data access requests can lead to potential data breaches and privacy violations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents in this scenario could be malicious insiders within Microsoft or unauthorized individuals who exploit vulnerabilities in the data access request process.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to customer data include potential leakage of sensitive information, violation of privacy regulations, and loss of trust from customers.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit a vulnerability in the Customer Lockbox review process to gain unauthorized access to log data in dedicated clusters, leading to the exposure of sensitive customer information. Alternatively, a malicious insider at Microsoft could abuse their privileges to access and misuse customer data without proper approval.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized access and data breaches due to non-compliant Azure resource configurations
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat description is related to unauthorized or non-compliant configurations within Azure resources, which could lead to security vulnerabilities and compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data and services.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include internal employees, external attackers, or malicious software exploiting misconfigured resources to gain unauthorized access, exfiltrate data, or disrupt services. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized changes to resource configurations, misconfigurations due to human error, or exploitation of unpatched vulnerabilities.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include potential data breaches, service disruption, unauthorized access, and loss of data integrity. Additionally, non-compliant configurations can lead to regulatory violations and financial penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits misconfigured Azure resources to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. By taking advantage of non-compliant configurations, the attacker is able to escalate privileges and exfiltrate sensitive information, leading to a significant data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

threat.name: Unauthorized public network access due to misconfigured ACLs
threat.desc:
General threat description
Disabling public network access using service-level IP ACL filtering or toggling switch for public network access introduces the risk of unauthorized access to the resources and potential exposure to malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors could attempt to bypass the IP ACL filtering or exploit misconfigured toggling switches to gain unauthorized access to the services. Additionally, attackers may attempt to intercept or manipulate network traffic to access restricted ports.
Impacts
The potential impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive resources, data breaches, exposure to malicious activities, and potential disruption of services or unauthorized monitoring and surveillance of workload environments.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits a misconfigured ACL filtering rule to gain unauthorized access to a service, allowing them to exfiltrate sensitive data or manipulate resources within the network. 2. A threat actor attempts to intercept and manipulate network traffic, exploiting the toggling switch for public network access to gain unauthorized entry into the environment and perform malicious activities.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-321
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-321: Use of Hard-coded Cryptographic Key The use of a hard-coded cryptographic key significantly increases the possibility that encrypted data may be recovered.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Enable threat detection capabilities
countermeasure.desc: Use the threat detection capability of Microsoft Defender for Cloud for the respective Azure services. For threat detection not included in Microsoft Defender services, refer to Microsoft Cloud Security Benchmark service baselines for the respective services to enable the threat detection or security alert capabilities within the service. Ingest alerts and log data from Microsoft Defender for Cloud, Microsoft 365 Defender, and log data from other resources into your Azure Monitor or Microsoft Sentinel instances to build analytics rules, which hunt detect threats and create alerts that match specific criteria across your environment. For Operational Technology (OT) environments that include computers that control or monitor Industrial Control System (ICS) or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) resources, use Microsoft Defender for IoT to inventory assets and detect threats and vulnerabilities. For services that do not have a native threat detection capability, consider collecting the data plane logs and analyze the threats through Microsoft Sentinel.

countermeasure.name: Ensure regular automated backups
countermeasure.desc: For Azure Backup supported resources (such as Azure VMs, SQL Server, HANA databases, Azure PostgreSQL Database, File Shares, Blobs or Disks), enable Azure Backup and configure the desired frequency and retention period. For Azure VM, you can use Azure Policy to have backup automatically enabled using Azure Policy. For resources or services not supported by Azure Backup, use the native backup capability provided by the resource or service. For example, Azure Key Vault provides a native backup capability. For resources/services that are neither supported by Azure Backup nor have a native backup capability, evaluate your backup and disaster needs, and create your own mechanism as per your business requirements. For example: - If you use Azure Storage for data storage, enable blob versioning for your storage blobs which will allow you to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your Azure Storage. - Service configuration settings can usually be exported to Azure Resource Manager templates.

countermeasure.name: Establish network segmentation boundaries
countermeasure.desc:
Create a virtual network (VNet) as a fundamental segmentation approach in your Azure network, so resources such as VMs can be deployed into the VNet within a network boundary. To further segment the network, you can create subnets inside VNet for smaller sub-networks.
Use network security groups (NSG) as a network layer control to restrict or monitor traffic by port, protocol, source IP address, or destination IP address. Refer to NS-7 Simplify network security configuration to use Adaptive Network Hardening to recommend NSG hardening rules based on threat intelligence and traffic analysis result.
You can also use application security groups (ASGs) to simplify complex configuration. Instead of defining policy based on explicit IP addresses in network security groups, ASGs enable you to configure network security as a natural extension of an application's structure, allowing you to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups.

countermeasure.name: Restrict resource access based on conditions
countermeasure.desc: Use Azure AD conditional access for more granular access controls based on user-defined conditions, such as requiring user logins from certain IP ranges (or devices) to use MFA. Azure AD Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organizations apps based on certain conditions. Define the applicable conditions and criteria for Azure AD conditional access in the workload. Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.name: Restrict the exposure of credential and secrets
countermeasure.desc:
When using a managed identity is not an option, ensure that secrets and credentials are stored in secure locations such as Azure Key Vault, instead of embedding them into the code and configuration files.
If you use Azure DevOps and GitHub for your code management platform: - Implement Azure DevOps Credential Scanner to identify credentials within the code. - For GitHub, use the native secret scanning feature to identify credentials or other forms of secrets within the code.
Clients such as Azure Functions, Azure Apps services, and VMs can use managed identities to access Azure Key Vault securely. See Data Protection controls related to the use of Azure Key Vault for secrets management.
Note: Azure Key Vault provides automatic rotation for supported services. For secrets which cannot be automatically rotated, ensure they are manually rotated periodically and purged when no longer in use.

countermeasure.name: Secure cloud native services with network controls
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy private endpoints for all Azure resources that support the Private Link feature, to establish a private access point for the resources. Using Private Link will keep the private connection from routing through the public network.
Note: Certain Azure services may also allow private communication through the service endpoint feature, though it is recommended to use Azure Private Link for secure and private access to services hosted on Azure platform.
For certain services, you can choose to deploy VNet integration for the service where you can restrict/isolate the VNET to establish a private access point for the service.
You also have the option to configure the service native network ACL rules or simply disable public network access to block access from the public network.
For Azure VMs, unless there is a strong use case, you should avoid assigning public IPs/subnet directly to the VM interface and instead use gateway or load balancer services as the front-end for access by the public network.

countermeasure.name: Separate and limit highly privileged/administrative users
countermeasure.desc:
You must secure all roles with direct or indirect administrative access to Azure hosted resources.
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's default identity and access management service. The most critical built-in roles in Azure AD are Global Administrator and Privileged Role Administrator, because users assigned to these two roles can delegate administrator roles. With these privileges, users can directly or indirectly read and modify every resource in your Azure environment: - Global Administrator / Company Administrator: Users with this role have access to all administrative features in Azure AD as well as services that use Azure AD identities. - Privileged Role Administrator: Users with this role can manage role assignments in Azure AD, as well as within Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM). In addition, this role allows management of all aspects of PIM and administrative units.
Outside of Azure AD, Azure has built-in roles that can be critical for privileged access at the resource level. - Owner: Grants full access to manage all resources, including the ability to assign roles in Azure RBAC. - Contributor: Grants full access to manage all resources, but does not allow you to assign roles in Azure RBAC, manage assignments in Azure Blueprints, or share image galleries. - User Access Administrator: Lets you manage user access to Azure resources. Note: You may have other critical roles that need to be governed if you use custom roles in the Azure AD level or resource level with certain privileged permissions assigned.
In addition, users with the following three roles in Azure Enterprise Agreement (EA) portal should also be restricted as they can be used to directly or indirectly manage Azure subscriptions. - Account Owner: Users with this role can manage subscriptions, including the creation and deletion of subscriptions. - Enterprise Administrator: Users assigned with this role can manage (EA) portal users. - Department Administrator: Users assigned with this role can change account owners within the department.
Lastly, ensure that you also restrict privileged accounts in other management, identity, and security systems that have administrative access to your business-critical assets, such as Active Directory Domain Controllers (DCs), security tools, and system management tools with agents installed on business-critical systems. Attackers who compromise these management and security systems can immediately weaponize them to compromise business critical assets.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

countermeasure.name: Use centralized identity and authentication system
countermeasure.desc:
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's identity and authentication management service. You should standardize on Azure AD to govern your organization's identity and authentication in: - Microsoft cloud resources, such as Azure Storage, Azure Virtual Machines (Linux and Windows), Azure Key Vault, PaaS, and SaaS applications. - Your organization's resources, such as applications on Azure, third-party applications running on your corporate network resources, and third-party SaaS applications. - Your enterprise identities in Active Directory by synchronization to Azure AD to ensure a consistent and centrally managed identity strategy.
For the Azure services that apply, avoid use of local authentication methods and instead use Azure Active Directory to centralize your service authentications.
Note: As soon as it is technically feasible, you should migrate on-premises Active Directory-based applications to Azure AD. This could be an Azure AD Enterprise Directory, Business to Business configuration, or Business to consumer configuration.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unapproved feature configuration increases security risks for the organization
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of security feature configuration exposes the organization to potential threats and vulnerabilities that may be exploited by attackers. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors could exploit misconfigured systems, unpatched software, or unsecured network connections to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data or compromise the integrity of the system. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive information, data breaches, disruption of services, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit a misconfigured security feature to gain unauthorized access to a sensitive database, exfiltrate valuable data, and potentially sell it on the dark web. Alternatively, an unpatched system could be exploited through a known vulnerability, leading to a ransomware attack that disrupts operations and causes significant financial losses to the organization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure||ATLAS - AML.T0010 - AI Supply Chain Compromise

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Misconfigured Azure resources can lead to security vulnerabilities and breaches
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured Azure resources can lead to security vulnerabilities and increase the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, and service disruptions. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigurations in Azure resources by leveraging automated tools to scan for weaknesses or by taking advantage of default settings or insecure configurations. 
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigurations in Azure resources can include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data exfiltration, service disruptions, compliance violations, and potential financial losses. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured storage account in Azure with public access enabled and is able to exfiltrate sensitive data. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting a misconfigured network security group to gain unauthorized access to a virtual machine.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations||ATLAS - AML.T0049 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Customer-managed key (CMK) encryption risk mitigated by Azure services
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to sensitive data at rest within Azure, on-premises, or Microsoft 365 environments. This threat exposes the data to potential theft or compromise, leading to compliance violations and loss of sensitive information. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents could be malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users exploiting vulnerabilities or misconfigurations in the data storage and encryption mechanisms. Attack vectors include unauthorized access to encryption keys, bypassing data loss prevention controls, and exploiting insecure data handling processes. 
Impacts
The impact of this threat includes regulatory non-compliance, data breaches, reputational damage, financial loss, and legal consequences resulting from unauthorized access, disclosure, or theft of sensitive data. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to encryption keys stored insecurely, allowing them to decrypt and exfiltrate sensitive data from Azure storage services. 2. A malicious insider circumvents data loss prevention controls and exfiltrates sensitive data from Microsoft 365 environments, leading to a data breach and compliance violations. 3. Exploiting weak key management practices, an unauthorized user compromises encryption keys stored in Azure Key Vault, undermining the confidentiality and integrity of the encrypted data at rest.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552 - Unsecured Credentials||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

threat.name: Unauthorized access attempt using embedded credentials in code or config files
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to the data plane and compromise of credentials and secrets, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data manipulation. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents may include malicious actors, internal employees, or external attackers who attempt to exploit vulnerabilities in the application or infrastructure to gain unauthorized access. Attack vectors may involve phishing attacks, credential stuffing, or exploitation of misconfigured access controls. 

Impacts
The impacts may include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data exfiltration, data manipulation, and potential disruption of services. Additionally, there may be reputational damage, financial losses, and regulatory non-compliance. 

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker utilizes a phishing campaign to acquire user credentials and gain unauthorized access to the data plane, potentially leading to data exfiltration or manipulation. Alternatively, an insider threat exploits local authentication methods to bypass Azure AD controls, compromising sensitive data and exposing the organization to substantial risk.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552 - Unsecured Credentials||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

threat.name: Unauthorized access leading to sensitive data compromise
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources can lead to data breaches and information compromise. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized actors with or without insider knowledge may attempt to gain access through methods such as credential theft, social engineering, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the authentication process. 
Impacts
If successful, unauthorized access can lead to the compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized modification or deletion of resources, and potential compliance violations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could attempt to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data stored in Azure Key Vault by stealing valid user credentials or exploiting vulnerabilities in the authentication process. By doing so, they could potentially retrieve secrets or access other critical resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

threat.name: Unauthorized access through public network vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description 

Public network access can lead to unauthorized access to resources, potential data breaches, and susceptibility to various cyber attacks. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors 

Threat agents can exploit open ports, weak network security configurations, and unsecured public network access to launch unauthorized access attempts, data exfiltration, or denial of service attacks. 

Impacts 

The impacts of unauthorized public network access include potential data breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive information, service disruption, and compromised system integrity. 

Example Attack Scenarios 

An attacker takes advantage of open ports and unsecured public network access to launch a brute force attack against the service, attempting to gain unauthorized access. Additionally, an attacker exploits weak network security configurations to intercept and exfiltrate sensitive data transmitted over the public network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATLAS - AML.T0006 - Active Scanning

threat.name: Unauthorized data access by Microsoft support personnel
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to sensitive data by internal or external entities poses a significant threat to the confidentiality and integrity of the organization's data and can lead to potential data breaches. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents can include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized individuals gaining access to local admin accounts. Attack vectors may involve compromised credentials, social engineering attacks, or exploitation of unsecured access points. 
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized data access can result in data exfiltration, exposure of sensitive information, financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences for the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a local admin account with extensive privileges and uses it to exfiltrate sensitive customer data or intellectual property. Alternatively, a malicious insider abuses their access to view and potentially misuse sensitive data without appropriate oversight or approval.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Credential exposure through insecure storage or embedding in code
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing secrets and credentials in code or configuration files exposes them to potential unauthorized access and compromise. Attackers often target these stored secrets to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data, systems, and resources. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and unauthorized third-party applications. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to code repositories, configuration file leaks, and exploitation of insecure storage mechanisms. 
Impacts
The compromise of stored secrets and credentials can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential regulatory non-compliance. This can result in financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a repository containing code with embedded credentials. By extracting these credentials, the attacker leverages them to access sensitive data stored in cloud services, causing a major data breach.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Undetected unauthorized activities due to lack of resource logs
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of comprehensive resource logs for the service increases the difficulty in detecting unauthorized access, malicious activities, or potential security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can exploit the absence of resource logs to perform unauthorized actions, access sensitive data, or compromise the integrity and availability of the service. Attack vectors may include attempts to access secrets, sensitive information, or execute unauthorized commands within the service.
Impacts
The absence of detailed resource logs increases the risk of undetected security breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and compromised service integrity. This can result in data leaks, compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a Key Vault and retrieves sensitive secrets undetected due to the absence of resource logs, resulting in unauthorized access to critical information. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting the lack of resource logs in an Azure SQL database to perform undetected malicious activities, potentially leading to data exfiltration or service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

weakness.name: CWE-1004
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1004: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag. The HttpOnly flag directs compatible browsers to prevent client-side script from accessing cookies. Including the HttpOnly flag in the Set-Cookie HTTP response header helps mitigate the risk associated with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) where an attacker's script code might attempt to read the contents of a cookie and exfiltrate information obtained. When set, browsers that support the flag will not reveal the contents of the cookie to a third party via client-side script executed via XSS.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Configure network security groups to allow only authorized traffic
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and configure Network Security Groups (NSGs) in Azure to enforce strict traffic control rules for Azure Web Apps. Define inbound and outbound rules to allow only authorized traffic, such as specific IP ranges, ports, or protocols necessary for application functionality. Deny all other traffic by default to reduce the attack surface. Regularly review and update NSG rules to ensure they align with security and operational requirements. Use Azure Firewall or Web Application Firewall (WAF) to further enhance protection against unauthorized access.

References

  • What is a Network Security Group?

countermeasure.name: Configure real-time alerts for unauthorized activities in Azure Web Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Set up real-time alerts in Azure Monitor or Microsoft Defender for Cloud to identify and respond promptly to unusual or unauthorized activities in Azure Web Apps. Configure alert rules for critical events such as multiple failed login attempts, unauthorized changes to configurations, or abnormal traffic patterns. Leverage diagnostic settings to send logs and metrics to Log Analytics or Event Hubs for centralized monitoring and correlation. Use automated workflows with Logic Apps or Azure Functions to initiate incident response actions like disabling compromised accounts or notifying administrators.

countermeasure.name: Enforce unique accounts for administrators on Azure Web Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that every administrator managing Azure Web Apps has a unique user account to enhance accountability and traceability. Avoid shared credentials to reduce the risk of unauthorized access and ensure that actions can be audited and attributed to specific individuals. Integrate these accounts with Azure Active Directory for centralized identity management and enforce strong authentication mechanisms such as multifactor authentication (MFA). Regularly review and deactivate unused or unnecessary administrator accounts to maintain a secure environment.

References

countermeasure.name: Ensure secure configuration of app settings for Azure Web Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Review and secure application settings to avoid the risks associated with default or weak configurations. Disable unnecessary features, enforce strong authentication for administrative interfaces, and restrict access to sensitive settings such as connection strings and API keys. Leverage Azure Key Vault to securely manage and store secrets, and apply strict access controls to prevent unauthorized modifications. Regularly audit app settings to ensure compliance with security best practices and mitigate the risk of exploitation.

countermeasure.name: Implement role-based access control for Azure Web Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Define and enforce Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) policies to restrict access to Azure Web Apps based on user roles and responsibilities. Assign roles using the principle of least privilege, ensuring users and applications have only the permissions necessary to perform their tasks. Use built-in roles or create custom roles tailored to your environment. Regularly audit and update RBAC policies to reflect changes in team responsibilities or application requirements, ensuring alignment with security best practices. Implementing RBAC minimizes the risk of unauthorized access and reduces the potential impact of compromised accounts or insider threats.

References

  • Role-Based Access Control in Azure

countermeasure.name: Regularly review and validate user access for Azure Web Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Conduct periodic reviews of user access permissions to ensure that all users have appropriate access levels to Azure Web Apps. Validate that roles and permissions align with the principle of least privilege, removing access for users who no longer require it. Use Azure Active Directory to manage user roles and track access changes. Implement automated alerts or workflows to detect and respond to unauthorized access modifications. This practice minimizes the risk of privilege escalation, unauthorized access, and potential data breaches.

countermeasure.name: Use Azure Key Vault to secure secrets and sensitive data
countermeasure.desc:
Protect secrets, sensitive data, and configuration values such as API keys, connection strings, and certificates by storing them in Azure Key Vault. This ensures that sensitive information is securely encrypted at rest and in transit. Configure Azure Web Apps to retrieve these secrets directly from Key Vault, eliminating the need to store them in application code or environment variables. Regularly rotate secrets, enforce access control policies, and monitor access logs to detect unauthorized access attempts.

countermeasure.name: Use tls to encrypt data in transit for Azure Web Apps
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all sensitive data transmitted between clients and services is encrypted using Transport Layer Security (TLS). This prevents unauthorized interception or tampering during data transfer. Configure Azure Web Apps to enforce HTTPS connections by redirecting HTTP traffic to HTTPS. Use the latest version of TLS (e.g., TLS 1.2 or higher) for optimal security and compliance with industry standards. Regularly review and update certificates to maintain a secure communication channel and prevent disruptions due to expired certificates.

References

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to root account
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized access to the root account occurs when attackers gain administrative control of Azure Web Apps, enabling them to alter configurations, access sensitive data, or deploy malicious applications. This often results from weak credentials, lack of multi-factor authentication, or leaked secrets.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, bots.
  • Vectors: Weak passwords, phishing, credential stuffing, or leaked secrets.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive data.
  • Service Disruption: Altered or disabled application components.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of user trust.
  • Non-Compliance: Regulatory violations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker brute-forces a weak root account password.
  2. Credentials leaked in a public GitHub repo are used to gain access.
  3. A phishing email tricks an admin into revealing root credentials.

threat.name: Unauthorized control of environment
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized control of the environment occurs when attackers gain the ability to manage and manipulate the Azure Web Apps environment, including configurations, resources, and deployments. This often results from misconfigurations, weak access controls, or compromised credentials.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, automated scripts.
  • Vectors: Exploiting misconfigured permissions, stealing access tokens or keys, or compromising privileged accounts.

Impacts

  • Service Downtime: Disruption or unavailability of web applications.
  • Malicious Modifications: Deployment of malicious code or resources.
  • Data Breach: Access to sensitive data or configurations.
  • Operational Risks: Loss of control over application environments.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits a misconfigured role assignment to gain administrative privileges over the application.
  2. Stolen API keys are used to deploy unauthorized resources or tamper with existing deployments.
  3. A malicious insider deliberately alters configurations, causing a denial of service or unauthorized access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Weak security configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Weak security configurations in Azure Web Apps occur when default, outdated, or improperly set security options leave applications vulnerable to exploitation. This includes insecure authentication, permissive access controls, and lack of encryption for data transmission or storage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Hackers, malicious insiders, automated bots.
  • Vectors: Exploiting default credentials, misconfigured access controls, or lack of encryption protocols.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive user or application data.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access or tampering with app functionality.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Violations of data protection laws.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits an application with default credentials that were not changed after deployment.
  2. Weak permissions on resources allow unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  3. Lack of HTTPS results in sensitive data being intercepted during transmission.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized network access occurs when attackers or unauthorized users gain entry to a network segment or system, potentially accessing sensitive resources or disrupting services. This can result from weak firewall rules, misconfigured security groups, or exposed network endpoints.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, automated bots.
  • Vectors: Exploiting open ports, poorly configured network security rules, or vulnerabilities in exposed endpoints.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Interference with or downtime of network-dependent systems.
  • Lateral Movement: Attackers moving through the network to exploit additional systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker scans for open ports and gains access to an exposed database server due to misconfigured security group rules.
  2. A malicious insider uses lax firewall policies to bypass restrictions and access restricted systems.
  3. A botnet exploits an unprotected network endpoint to launch a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to data storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized access to data storage occurs when attackers or unauthorized users gain access to databases or storage systems, allowing them to view, modify, or delete sensitive data. This can result from weak authentication, misconfigured permissions, or exposed endpoints.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, bots.
  • Vectors: Exploiting weak access controls, leaked credentials, or improperly secured storage configurations.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive information.
  • Data Tampering: Unauthorized modification of critical data.
  • Data Loss: Deletion or corruption of stored information.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from users or stakeholders.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits weak database credentials to gain unauthorized access.
  2. Misconfigured permissions on a storage bucket expose private files to public access.
  3. A malicious insider accesses customer data stored in the database without authorization.

threat.name: Data exposure during transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data exposure during transmission occurs when sensitive information, such as user credentials or application data, is transmitted over unencrypted or poorly secured communication channels, making it susceptible to interception by attackers.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insiders, network eavesdroppers.
  • Vectors: Exploiting the use of HTTP, outdated encryption protocols, or insecure APIs.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Compromise of sensitive user or application data.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attacks: Alteration or interception of data during transmission.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of data protection standards like GDPR or PCI DSS.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted HTTP traffic to steal user login credentials.
  2. Weak TLS settings allow exploitation of known vulnerabilities to decrypt sensitive communications.
  3. API calls made over insecure protocols leak sensitive application data to unauthorized parties.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1214 - Credentials in Registry

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insufficient logging and monitoring occurs when systems fail to adequately record or analyze activities, leading to undetected security incidents, delayed response times, and incomplete forensic investigations. This can stem from a lack of centralized logging, incomplete log data, or failure to set up alerting for suspicious activities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unmonitored automated processes.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unmonitored activities, bypassing existing controls without detection, or triggering unlogged security events.

Impacts

  • Undetected Breaches: Prolonged attacker presence within systems.
  • Delayed Incident Response: Slow detection and mitigation of security events.
  • Compliance Failures: Breach of logging and monitoring requirements for regulatory frameworks like GDPR or SOC 2.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to a system, and the activity goes unnoticed due to disabled audit logs.
  2. A privileged insider misuses administrative credentials without triggering any alerts.
  3. A malware infection spreads through the network while logs fail to capture abnormal traffic patterns.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-345
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-345: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-502
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data The product deserializes untrusted data without sufficiently verifying that the resulting data will be valid.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure all sensitive data is encrypted both at rest and in transit to protect against unauthorized access.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Identify sensitive data that requires encryption based on classification and regulatory requirements.
  2. Use strong encryption algorithms and manage keys securely using a dedicated key management system.
  3. Configure encryption for all data storage solutions, including databases, file systems, and backups.
  4. Ensure that data transmission channels use protocols such as TLS/SSL for secure communication.
  5. Regularly review and update encryption policies to align with evolving security standards.

Implementing these steps will significantly reduce the risk of sensitive data exposure.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Data Encryption

countermeasure.name: Enhance file logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Implement comprehensive logging and monitoring to detect and respond to unauthorized file access and modifications.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Enable detailed logging for all file access and modification activities.
  2. Use centralized logging solutions to collect and analyze log data.
  3. Set up alerts for suspicious activities or patterns indicative of security incidents.
  4. Regularly review and audit log files to ensure they provide complete and accurate records.
  5. Implement real-time monitoring tools to detect and respond to threats promptly.

Implementing these steps will enhance your ability to detect and respond to unauthorized file activities.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Logging and Monitoring

countermeasure.name: Implement metadata integrity checks
countermeasure.desc:
Use integrity checking mechanisms to monitor and protect file metadata from unauthorized modifications.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Employ file integrity monitoring (FIM) tools to track changes in file metadata.
  2. Regularly audit file permissions, ownership, and other metadata attributes to ensure they are correctly configured.
  3. Use cryptographic methods to ensure the integrity of critical metadata.
  4. Set up alerts for unauthorized changes to file metadata and take immediate action to address them.
  5. Educate administrators on the importance of metadata integrity and how to maintain it.

Implementing these steps will help maintain the integrity of file metadata and prevent unauthorized modifications.

reference.name: File Integrity Monitoring

countermeasure.name: Implement robust access controls
countermeasure.desc:
Implement strict access control mechanisms using principles of least privilege and need-to-know.

Regularly audit and update ACLs to ensure they are correctly configured.

Use encryption to protect sensitive files both at rest and in transit.

Implement monitoring and logging to detect unauthorized access attempts.

Educate employees about the importance of file security and proper handling procedures.

countermeasure.name: Secure file upload handling
countermeasure.desc:
Validate and sanitize all uploaded files to ensure they do not contain malicious code.

Implement file type restrictions to allow only safe file formats.

Use antivirus software to scan uploaded files for malware.

Store uploaded files in isolated directories and execute them in a sandbox environment.

Educate users about the risks of uploading and sharing files from untrusted sources.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Ransomware encrypting files
threat.desc:
General threat description: Ransomware encrypts files and demands a ransom for their decryption, causing data loss and operational disruptions.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Cybercriminals distribute ransomware through phishing emails, malicious websites, or exploiting software vulnerabilities.

Impacts: Loss of access to critical data, financial loss, operational downtime, and potential data breach.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An employee opens a malicious email attachment, triggering ransomware that encrypts the companys file server.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in remote desktop services to deploy ransomware.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Malware infection via file uploads
threat.desc:
General threat description: Malware infection via file uploads occurs when an attacker uploads malicious files that are executed or processed by the system, leading to compromise.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers upload infected files through web applications or email attachments.

Impacts: System compromise, data loss, and propagation of malware.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uploads a file containing a script that exploits a vulnerability in the file processing service.
  • A user inadvertently uploads a document infected with a macro virus.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data exposure due to inadequate encryption
threat.desc:
General threat description: Sensitive data exposure occurs when files containing confidential information are not properly encrypted, making them vulnerable to unauthorized access.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malicious insiders, or malware can exploit weak or absent encryption mechanisms.

Impacts: Data breaches, financial loss, legal consequences, and damage to reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker intercepts data being transmitted over an unencrypted channel.
  • A malicious insider accesses and exfiltrates unencrypted sensitive files from the storage.

threat.name: Unauthorized file access
threat.desc:
General threat description: Unauthorized file access occurs when an attacker gains access to files without proper authorization, potentially leading to data breaches.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malicious insiders, malware, or exploited vulnerabilities in software can lead to unauthorized access.

Impacts: Exposure of sensitive information, financial loss, legal consequences, and damage to reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the file system to bypass ACLs and access confidential documents.
  • A disgruntled employee uses elevated permissions to access and exfiltrate proprietary information.

threat.name: Insufficient file logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description: Insufficient file logging and monitoring can lead to delayed detection of unauthorized access, tampering, or other malicious activities.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malicious insiders, or malware can exploit the lack of comprehensive logging and monitoring.

Impacts: Delayed response to security incidents, data breaches, and operational disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker accesses sensitive files without being detected due to lack of logging.
  • Unauthorized modifications to critical files go unnoticed, leading to data integrity issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized modification of file metadata
threat.desc:
General threat description: Unauthorized modification of file metadata occurs when an attacker alters metadata information such as file permissions, ownership, or timestamps, leading to potential misuse or abuse of the file system.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malicious insiders, or malware can exploit vulnerabilities in file system management.

Impacts: Data integrity issues, unauthorized access, and operational disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker changes the file permissions to gain unauthorized access to sensitive files.
  • A malicious insider alters timestamps to cover up unauthorized activities.

threat.name: File corruption or tampering
threat.desc:
General threat description: File corruption or tampering occurs when an attacker modifies files, potentially leading to data integrity issues and unauthorized alterations.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: External attackers, malware, or malicious insiders can alter file contents or metadata.

Impacts: Data integrity compromise, operational disruptions, and loss of trust in the data.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker injects malicious code into executable files to introduce malware.
  • A malicious insider alters financial records to commit fraud.

weakness.name: CWE-1095
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1095: Loop Condition Value Update within the Loop The product uses a loop with a control flow condition based on a value that is updated within the body of the loop.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Configure sharing permissions to restrict access to authorized users
countermeasure.desc:
Set up sharing permissions in Microsoft Power BI to ensure that only authorized users can access specific reports and dashboards. To implement this, use the Power BI service to define sharing settings at the workspace, report, and dashboard levels. Restrict access by using specific email addresses, security groups, or distribution lists for sharing. Configure role-based access controls (RBAC) within the workspace to limit user permissions to "Viewer," "Contributor," or "Admin" based on their role. Regularly audit shared content to verify that access permissions align with current organizational policies. This control minimizes the risk of data leakage and ensures sensitive reports are only accessible to authorized individuals.

References

  • Power BI Security Overview

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Define roles and rules for row-level security
countermeasure.desc:
Implement Row-Level Security (RLS) in Microsoft Power BI to restrict data access based on user roles, ensuring users can only view data pertinent to their responsibilities. Use the Power BI Desktop to define roles and create DAX filters that enforce data visibility at the row level. Publish the report to the Power BI service and assign roles to specific users or security groups. Regularly review and update RLS configurations to align with organizational changes and ensure compliance with data security policies. This approach minimizes the risk of unauthorized data access and enhances data governance.

References

  • Power BI Security White Paper

countermeasure.name: Ensure data encryption for Power BI storage
countermeasure.desc:
Enable encryption for all data stored in Microsoft Power BI to protect against unauthorized access. Power BI automatically encrypts data at rest using Microsoft-managed keys. To enhance security, organizations can enable customer-managed keys (CMKs) to control encryption processes. Configure and manage CMKs using Azure Key Vault and assign them to Power BI storage. Regularly rotate keys and monitor their usage to maintain encryption integrity. This control ensures that sensitive data remains confidential and complies with organizational and regulatory requirements.

References

  • Data Protection in Power BI

countermeasure.name: Set up monitoring to track user activities and detect suspicious behavior
countermeasure.desc:
Configure monitoring in Microsoft Power BI to track user activities, access patterns, and report usage, ensuring timely detection and response to suspicious behavior. Enable audit logs in the Power BI admin portal to capture details about report views, data exports, and sharing activities. Integrate Power BI activity logs with Microsoft Sentinel or other SIEM solutions for advanced analysis and alerting. Set up automated alerts for anomalous behavior, such as unusual data access patterns or repeated failed login attempts. Regularly review activity logs to identify potential security incidents and refine monitoring rules to align with organizational policies.

References

  • Power BI Security Overview

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized data access in Microsoft Power BI occurs when individuals gain access to reports, dashboards, or datasets without proper authorization. This can result from weak access controls, misconfigured sharing settings, or compromised accounts, leading to the exposure of sensitive business information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit weak authentication or compromised accounts to access Power BI resources.
  • Insiders: Malicious or negligent employees accessing data beyond their role or need.
  • Misconfigured Permissions: Overly permissive or incorrect access configurations expose data to unauthorized users.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of confidential information such as financial reports or customer data.
  • Compliance Failures: Violations of data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer and partner trust due to mishandling of sensitive information.
  • Financial Losses: Costs related to incident remediation, fines, and potential lawsuits.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Account Access: An attacker uses stolen credentials to access a Power BI workspace containing sensitive sales data.
  2. Excessive Permissions Misuse: An internal user with access to all datasets views confidential HR data they are not authorized to see.
  3. Misconfigured Sharing: A Power BI report containing proprietary analytics is shared with external users due to improperly configured sharing settings.

threat.name: Data leakage through sharing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data leakage through sharing occurs when sensitive Power BI reports or dashboards are shared with unauthorized users due to improper sharing configurations. This can result in the exposure of confidential or sensitive business information, violating privacy regulations and damaging organizational trust.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees or contractors accidentally or intentionally sharing data with unauthorized recipients.
  • External Attackers: Exploiting overly permissive sharing settings to gain access to shared data.
  • Misconfigured Settings: Inadequate controls over sharing permissions, leading to unintended data exposure.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Confidential business information is accessed by unauthorized users.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of data protection regulations such as GDPR or HIPAA.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to exposed sensitive data.
  • Financial Losses: Costs associated with incident response, legal penalties, and remediation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unintended Sharing with External Users: An employee accidentally shares a report containing financial data with an external email address, exposing the organizations internal financial performance.
  2. Exploiting Public Links: An attacker gains access to a publicly shared Power BI dashboard that contains sensitive customer data due to improper access restrictions.
  3. Unauthorized Forwarding: An internal user forwards a shared link to a Power BI report to an unauthorized party, granting them access to sensitive information.

threat.name: Insecure data storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure data storage in Microsoft Power BI refers to sensitive data being stored without proper encryption or access controls. This can result in unauthorized access to critical business information, exposing the organization to data breaches, compliance violations, and reputational damage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit weak encryption or misconfigured storage to access sensitive data.
  • Insiders: Employees or contractors accessing unprotected data without proper authorization.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Improper setup of Power BI storage settings, leaving data unencrypted or accessible to unauthorized users.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive data such as financial reports, customer details, or proprietary analytics.
  • Compliance Failures: Violations of regulations like GDPR, CCPA, or HIPAA due to improper data protection.
  • Operational Disruptions: Alteration or corruption of unprotected data, affecting business decision-making.
  • Financial Losses: Costs associated with legal penalties, remediation, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage Access: An attacker exploits weak security on Power BI storage and retrieves customer data that was not encrypted.
  2. Improper File Permissions: An internal user accesses confidential financial reports stored in Power BI due to misconfigured access controls.
  3. Data Exfiltration via Misconfigured Backup: Backup copies of Power BI reports stored in an unprotected location are accessed and exfiltrated by an unauthorized user.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring and auditing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insufficient monitoring and auditing in Microsoft Power BI refers to a lack of visibility into user activities, access patterns, and data interactions. This absence of oversight makes it difficult to detect unauthorized access, suspicious behaviors, or data misuse, increasing the risk of prolonged exposure to security threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit the lack of monitoring to perform unauthorized actions undetected.
  • Insiders: Malicious or negligent employees misuse their access without being flagged.
  • Compromised Accounts: Hijacked accounts perform malicious actions without triggering alerts.

Impacts

  • Undetected Data Breaches: Prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive reports or dashboards.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to meet regulatory requirements for activity tracking and reporting.
  • Operational Risks: Missed opportunities to identify and respond to anomalies, leading to data misuse or loss.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust due to delayed responses to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Undetected Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to a Power BI workspace using compromised credentials and exfiltrates sensitive reports without being detected due to lack of activity monitoring.
  2. Data Misuse by Insider: An employee with access to confidential dashboards downloads sensitive data and shares it externally without triggering any alerts.
  3. Delayed Breach Detection: Suspicious login attempts are ignored because audit logs are not enabled or monitored, allowing attackers to persist in the environment.
